ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 8.--The Republicans of the Second District to-day nominated Vreeland H. Youngman for member of Assembly.

The opening of an art gallery in the Eden Musee has proved a success, as the attendance so far has increased fully 100 per cent., bringing a class of people who never before thought of visiting the Musee. Giron's painting of the "Two Sisters" appears to be the feature of the exhibition, although the Grolleron, "La Papotte," and Dawant's "Departure of Emigrants from Havre," attract a good deal of attention.

Although the Mormons of Utah have framed in convention and adopted at the polls a Constitution in which polygamy is forbidden and declared to be a penitentiary offense, the Federal courts in the Territory are still busily engaged with cases under the anti-polygamy laws.
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 9.--St. Louis, 6; Cleveland, 2. Base hits--St. Louis, 12; Cleveland, 6. Errors--St. Louis, O; Cleveland, 5. Batteries--King and Boyle; Gilks and Zimmer.

The race around Long Island was won late on Saturday night by Mr. John R. Hatch's 45-foot centreboard sloop Fanita against the extreme cutter Ulidia. It goes on record as being the fastest time ever made over that course by many hours, the distance sailed being about 200 miles.
The attention of mariners is called by Lieut. Cottman to the change in station of the Coast Survey steamer Blake, now making investigation of the currents in the approaches to this city.

CHICAGO, Oct. 9.--George Francis Train opened his campaign in Chicago at the Princess's Theatre this afternoon before an audience of 600. Nearly all the Socialists and Anarchists were present and greeted Mr. Train with a cheer.

CHICAGO, Oct. 9.--It is said that the greatest week's business ever done in this country by any dramatic organization has been exceeded by Booth and Barrett at the Chicago Opera House the last week. Certain it is that such business has never been done in Chicago.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 9.--A train containing Gov. Foraker, State Librarian Doane and a large delegation of Zanesville people en route to Zanesville, where the Governor delivered an addrecs, was derailed near Roseville, 10 miles south of Zanesville, last night by a defective switch.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 9.--The announcement that the Rev. Warren A. Candler, Pastor of the McKendree Church, would preach a sermon on theatre-going attracted a very large congregation at the morning service to-day. Mr. Candler, who was recently appointed to the pastorate of the church, is also associate editor of the Nashville Christian Advocate.

Mrs. Ella Robinson, the wife of Charles Robinson, a wholesale hardware merchant of Louisville, jumped from a third-story front window at 106 Madison-avenue yesterday afternoon and sustained injuries from which she died a few hours later.

TUCSON, Arizona, Oct. 9.--The United States Grand Jury, in session here has discovered that organized cattle thieves have been stealing cattle from the Indians on the San Carlos Reservation during the past year. Several prominent citizens are implicated.

MONTREAL, Oct. 9.--The Hon. J.A. Chapleau, Secretary of State, arrived here from England today. He says that the Fishery Commission is looked upon favorably in London, and that Joseph Chamberlain is the best man that could be selected.

CHICAGO, Oct. 9.--The indications are that not only the various freight associations of the Western roads will go out of existence on account of the inability of the various roads forming those associations to harmonize their conflicting interests, but that the Western States Passenger Association will also have to quit business for the same reasons.

The horsemen who flock to Fleetwood every Sunday made a busy day of it yesterday. The track was only excelled by the fine weather for inducements to trot, and the flyers were speeded from daylight to dusk.

BINGHAMTON, Oct. 9.--The Democratic Senatorial Convention of the Twenty-sixth District met at Sidney yesterday afternoon and unanimously nominated Robert L. Johnson, of Franklin, for Senator.

Mays pitched a good game against the Brooklyns at Ridgwood Park yesterday, and the result was that the Mets won a game from the Brooklyns. Terry was also effective, but he was given poor support, especially at third base, where Pinkney distinguished himself by fumbling every ball batted in his direction.

The pigeon shooters will be busy on Long Island this week. The Acme Gun Club will shoot at Dexter Park to-morrow; the Unknown Gun Club at the same place Thursday; the Coney Island Rod and Gun Club at Woodlawn Wednesday; the North Side Gun Club at Woodside to-morrow, and the Falcon Gun Club at Durdler's, East New-York, Thursday.

The sudden departure of Mr. Robert Garrett for Baltimore yesterday afternoon, accompanied by Dr. Metcalf, of this city, as stated in the appended special dispatch, gave rise to rumors at once surprising and painful. They were in effect that his mental faculties had become affected and he had been taken home for treatment.

The Staten Island Cricket Club has just finished a most prosperous season. Out of 19 first eleven matches 11 have been won, 7 lost, and 1 drawn. The second eleven lost 5, won 4, and drew 1. Cyril Wilson won the G.L.

--George O. Seilhamer, of Philadelphia, will publish some time in December a history of the stage in this country before the Revolution, the work comprising one volume of over 300 pages. Only 500 copies will be issued, and these to subscribers.

LONDON, Oct. 9.--Discount was easy during the past week at 2 @3. Business on the Stock Exchange was irregular. Early in the week there was an appearance of healthy activity. This was followed by renewed dullness, and the dealings for investment became very limited.

SOFIA, Oct. 9.--The elections to-day were orderly. Soldiers patrolied the streets and guarded the public buildings. All the Government candidates here are elected. Stambuloff received 3,020 votes, Stransky 2,915, and Gueshoff 2,873.

In the British House of Lords, a few weeks ago, Earl DE LA WARR asked whether the Government had been trying to prevent the sale of liquors to the natives on the Pacific islands and elsewhere.

The Union-square police blunder at the Progressive Labor Party ratification meeting Saturday night was the subject of much talk in many circles, especially among the working classes, yesterday. Everybody who was witness to the exciting scene had a story to tell peculiarly his own, but the substance of the descriptions did not differ materially from that printed in THE TIMES.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 9.--Richard Shaffer, aged 42 years, an Englishman, lies in the Rhode Island Hospital suffering from injuries which will probably prove fatal in a few days, and the manner in which he obtained them is shrouded in mystery.

D.--a man whose honorable career as statesman and diplomat, has won him the respect of men of all parties in this country and the friendship of many eminent people in Europe.

The village of Breslau, Long Island, which was a few months ago the scene of the mysterious murder of old Philip Scheidmiller and his young wife, has been shocked by another crime, perpetrated Saturday night within 200 feet of the Scheidmiller house.

CITY OF MEXICO, Oct. 9.--There were very exciting times in the suburban village of Guadeloupe Hidalgo yesterday over the report that an architect had arrived at the Collegiate Church with the object of removing the image of the Virgin of Guadeloupe, concerning which there is much superstition.

Mayor Hewitt has sought to earn a reputation as an opponent of all public and private abuses, and in some cases he has undoubtedly followed in the footsteps of his predecessor and thereby gained the good-will of a large number of citizens.

Among the many attractions at the fair of the Anti-Poverty Society, which has been going on at the Madison-Square Garden for several weeks, is a large portrait of Father McGlynn, which was to be disposed of by a raffle at 25 cents a chance.
PARIS, Oct. 9.--Maurice Strakosch, the trainer of Mme. Patti, is dead.

Below will be found the standing of the clubs in the League and American Association. The League season closed on Saturday. Detroit took first place, Philadelphia second, Chicago third, New-York fourth, Boston fifth, Pittsburg sixth, Washington seventh, and Indianapolis eighth.
The American bark Oasis, Capt. Chadbourne, left Philadelphia for Hiogo with a cargo of oil on Aug. 23. On Sept. 1, when in the neighborhood of the West Indies, the vessel was caught in a hurricane.

HELENA, Montana, Oct. 9.--An exciting foot race took place yesterday between Fred Stone, of Philadelphia, and Billy Barker, an Australian sprinter, for $500. The distance was 100 yards, and Fred Stone won, beating his opponent 10 yards. The time was 0:9 , the fastest time on record. Over $10,000 changed hands on the race.

A.F. Troescher and H.W. Collender were to have left this city Saturday night for Chicago to attend the wedding of a daughter of Moses Bensinger, but it will be a part of their purpose to placate George F. Slosson, who wishes to have the tournament proposed for Chicago take place before that intended for this city.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Oct. 9.--John F. Oxner, a white farmer, living in the Broad River section of Newberry County, was killed yesterday by a colored man whom he had ordered off his place. The murderer escaped.

All sorts of rowing craft shot up and down on the Harlem all day yesterday, for the athletic fellows who have enjoyed the Summer on the stream and lived in the boathouses cannot expect this sort of weather to last much longer.
PORTLAND, Oregon, Oct. 9.--All printers in all the job offices here struck yesterday afternoon. The strike was not authorized by the Multnomah Typographical Union, of which they were members.

A site for the great cathedral which is to be built in this city by the members of the Protestant Episcopal Church has been all but definitely chosen, and negotiations have been going on for its purchase for months.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 9.--The revenue cutter Richard Rush arrived from the arctic to-day via Victoria. She reports that during the season she seized 12 sealing schooners, with a total of nearly 7,000 skins. The Russian authorities have seized three sealers on the Siberian coast--one American, one British, and a third, nationality unknown.
LONDON, Oct. 9.--The steamship Halley, (Br.,) Capt. Holt, from New-York Sept. 25, arr. at Liverpool to-day.
RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 9.--Gov. Fitzhugh Lee to-night characterized Judge Bond's action in the contempt cases as an outrageous attack upon the Constitution and the rights of the State.
The steamboat Melzingah, owned by Harry Hill, and for some years plying between Flushing and this city as a freight boat, sunk Saturday night off Riker's Island.

The Republican ratification meeting on Saturday evening was not an imposing one, and there were few things read with less interest in the big volumes issued from the newspaper offices on Sunday morning than were the various reports of the meeting.

BUFFALO, Oct. 9.--The bankers' view of the financial prospects and commercial prosperity of this great and growing country is certainly a most encouraging one. This is, in brief, the feeling as gathered from an interview with Dr. George Marsland, Secretary of the American Bankers' Association, which meets in Pittsburg this week:

It was stated yesterday that a petition was being circulated among lawyers and Custom House brokers asking Secretary Fairchild to remove Collector Magone because they did not get back the duties to be refunded under the Oberteufer decision as rapidly as desirable.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 9.--There is a considerable increase of diphtheria in various sections of the State. Dr. E.M. Hunt, Secretary of the State Board of Health, thinks this is largely due to damp cellars which are suddenly heated in the Fall.

CHICAGO, Oct. 9.--The Farmers' Review crop summary this week is as follows: The scarcity of pasture and the shortage of the hay crop, owing to the continued drought during the Summer months, have led this year to the cutting of a larger amount of corn fodder throughout the West than ever before by farmers who have stock to winter.

SALT LAKE, Utah, Oct. 9.--Yesterday was the third day of the Mormon Conference. Wilford Woodruff. President of the Twelve Apostles, read a long epistle referring to the state of the church and the Mormon people and to the death of John Taylor, saying the church was now in the hands of the Twelve, which was supposed to mean that they will not elect a President at this Conference.
Mr. Kyrle Bellew returned from Europe yesterday on the Etruria. His face and his little tinkling silver bell were both very bright when seen by a TIMES reporter yesterday.

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 9.--A flood of wheat was poured into Minneapolis yesterday, and a great deal of it stopped over on the sample tables. The total receipts were 234,000 bushels, and of this 47,000 bushels were shipped. Large receipts are expected next week if the weather is favorable.

CHICAGO, Oct. 9.--A preliminary meeting to organize a command in Chicago of the Society of Veterans of the regular army and navy was held last night in Grand Army Hall, and a permanent organization may be effected soon.

MADISON, Wis., Oct. 9.--President Cleveland appeared at the reception last night after his fishing excursion looking as dressy as if he had not during the afternoon caught fish and cut bait. The afternoon's recreation did him an immense amount of good.
Chickering Hall was appropriately embellished with mourning emblems at the meeting of the American Temperance Union yesterday afternoon.
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 9.--The Detroit champions arrived this evening, but owing to the rain the baseball parade in honor of the two champion teams was postponed until to-morrow.

The Anti-Poverty Society of Newark met yesterday afternoon in the Grand Opera House, on Washington-street. Henry George, Judge James Maguire, of California; John McMackin, and the Rev. H.O. Pentecost made speeches on the usual topics and in the usual way.
The New-Yorks will play at Nyack, N.Y., today.

BUFFALO, Oct. 9.--Lyman Smith has spent some years in perfecting a pneumatic grain transfer elevator. For three years past or thereabout he has been at Cleveland, where he has built his machine and protected it by 14 patents.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, Oct. 9.--Something of a sensation was caused yesterday at the Mormon Conference by the appearance in the pulpit of Apostle Erastus Snow, who preached a long discourse.

The Rev. Dr. Morgan Dix, of Trinity Parish, arrived with his wife and children yesterday morning on the Cunard steamship Etruria. The Rector was looking unusually well and appeared to have profited by the months which he has spent abroad.

Baron Paul Vletinghoff, who last Winter taught untitled Americans how to ride a horse in an up-town riding school, was married yesterday at 111 West Forty-seventh-street to Miss Louise Fielder. BOSTON, Mass., Oct. 10.--In the District Court to-day Dennis J. Lordan was arraigned on a charge of assaulting Patrick Corbett last Saturday night. He pleaded not guilty, and was released on $3,000 bonds for further appearance on Friday, pending the result of Corbett's injuries.

Maurice Strakosch, whose death in Paris was announced yesterday, was born at Seelowitz, a little town near Brunn, in Moravia, 63 years ago. He was a little prodigy, having made a sensation at Brunn at the age of 11 with his execution on the piano of a concerto by Hummel, the Liszt of the time.

Since Bargy's conviction the law has been changed. making ten years the limit of punishment in similar cases.

NORFOLK, Oct. 11.--The Clyde Line Steamer George H. Stont, running between Philadelphia, Norfolk, and New-Berne, N. C., was burned at her wharf in New-Berne Sunday night. BOSTON, Oct. 12.--At a meeting of the creditors of F.C. Davenport, metal dealer, to-day, his liabilities were stated at $101,614, of which 85,000 is unsecured, and the assets at $47,500. An offer of 12 per cent. was not accepted.

Bandmaster C.A. Cappa, of the Seventh Regiment, has just received from the King of Italy the Cross of the Order of Honor, creating him a Chevalier, for his musical merit. This is an honor seldom conferred upon a person living in this country. In consequence of this decoration Mr. Cappa was immediately elected honorary President of the Society of Good Merit, in Palermo, Italy.

The Columbia Freshmen met yesterday and decided to meet to-morrow at the Buckingham Hotel and march over to the college carry ing canes to test the patience of the Sophomores in their refusal to rush the Freshmen. The Sophomores say that they exepect to keep their good resolutions.

The Attorney-General, upon the application of Augustus Baus and Charles Baumeister, two of the three Trustees of Augustus Baus Co., a piano factory firm, at 58 West Twentythird-street, has obtained from Judge Donohue a decree dissolving that corporation and appointing Gustavus Baylies, Jr., who has been its Secretary for many years, its Receiver.

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 12.--A few months ago Mr. Tartaglia, the bandmaster aboard the United States flagship, Richmond, composed a march called "President Cleveland's March," which was forwarded to the President, accepted, published, and circulated about the country.

NOGALES, Arizona, Oct. 12.--One of the most disastrous storms ever known on the southern coast of Mexico occurred on the 7th and 8th insts. The city of Quelito, a town of more than 5,000 people, was totally destroyed and many lives lost.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 12.--The intercollegiate lawn tennis tourney made good progress on the grouuds of the New-Haven Club today. Sears, of Harvard, brother of the champion of the world.
PARIS, Oct. 12.--A summary of the plan for the mobilization of the Seventeenth Army Corps, which was divulged by the Figaro, has been found in the house of Gen. Caffarel.

Annie Overton, the 8-year-old daughter of Mr. Edgar Overton, of East Patchogue, Long Island, was fatally wounded Tuesday night by the accidental discharge of a revolver which she pulled out of a bureau drawer and let fall on the floor. The charge entered her abdomen.

Parsons yesterday. According to its provisions the widow of the testator is to have the Bergen Point homestead and the income of $100,000.

ALBANY, Oct. 12.--The Republicans of Albany County nominated a strong ticket at Coeymans Junction to-day. Dr. John Swinburne was named for Congressman, Henry Russell for Ssnator, and John Battersby for County Treasurer.

HARTFORD, Conn. Oct. 12.--The Rev. F.W. Tompkins, of New-York, has been invited to the Rectorship of Christ Church, in this city, by the Vestry, and it is believed here that he will accept. The Rev. Dr. Lindsay, of Georgetown, D.C., declined the position a few weeks ago, accepting instead the Bridgeport Rectorship. Christ Church has one of the largest and richest parishes in the State.

Manager Abbey's policy of supplying the patrons of Wallack's with a number of comedy performances during the season, instead of seking to produce any one play for a long run, is to be faithfully followed.

The New-York District Railway Company has again invited the property owners along its route to give their consent to its construction. The company professes to think that it has been helped by the recent decision of the Court of Appeals.

Lawson N. Fuller, who was in the sugar refining business for 25 years, and who is now building a sugarhouse preparatory to re-enter ing the business, said, in reference to the proposed formation of a Sugar Refiners' Trust mentioned in yesterday's TIMES:

Michael J. Collins, a resident of Staten Island, in 1884 sold the steam launch Eclipse to Thomas Manning, a ship broker of this city. Manning sold the launch to other persons, and a dispute arose between him and Collins about the representations in regard to the launch which Collins had made him. So bitter did the dispute grow that Manning had Collins arrested for fraud, and ineffectually endeavored to get the ...

The flags presented by Archbishop Croke, of Cashel, Ireland, to the Sirty-ninth Regiment and to the Rev. John J. Riordan, of Castle Garden, wore viewed for the first time last evening at a reception to the officers of the regiment at Father Riordan's Mission of the Holy Rosary, 7 State-street.

The body of Gen. Kilpatrick, accompanied by his family, arrival here last night from Aspinwall on the steamship New-York. A meeting will be held at the Astor House this morning at 8 o'clock to make final arrangements for the burial at Deckertown, N.J.

DETROIT, Oct. 12.--It took 13 innings to decide the third game between Detroit and St. Louis for the world's championship and Detroit won it through wretched fielding on the part of the visitors. The Browns secured 16 hits off ...

LONDON, Oct. 12.--The Middle Park Plate, for 2-year-olds, which was run for at Newmarket to-day, was won by Friar's Balsam by a length and a half, with Hazlehatch second and Seabreeze third. The first two are half brothers, both being sons of Hermit. Friar's Balsam was a hot favorite, the betting being 9 to 4 on him to win.

CITY OF MEXICO, Oct. 12, via Galveston.--The news of the death of Judge Manning, United States Minister to Mexico, caused a profound sensation here, and all the foreign legations will take appropriate action Thomas B. Connery, Charge d' Affaires of the United States, is to-day receiving the condolences of officials and private persons.

The feeling between the locked-out brassworkers and the chandelier manufacturers seemed to grow more bitter yesterday. The manufacturers appear to want to starve the men into submission, and the men to force the bosses to accede to their demands for the continuance of the Saturday half-holiday.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Oct. 12.--A fierce fire visited the Insane Asylum on the southern limits of the city for the second time to-night. It was the occasion of the weekly dance given the more manageable of the patients as a healthy means of recreation.

At the meeting of the Central Wine and Liquor Dealers' Association on Tuesday it was reported by a committee that an effort had been made to secure the assistance of the police in the interests of the liquor men in political matters through the influence of Subway Commissioner Hess.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Oct. 12.--In the threeminute class race at the Hudson River Driving Park, to-day, Confederate Maid won the first heat in 2:34 and Annie W. the next three heats in 2:37 , 2:34 , and 2:35. The 2:27 class race was won in straight heats by Bergen in 2:29 , 2:27 , and 2:27 .
Mr. James Bell, the principal owner, and Mr. G.L. Watson, the designer, of the Thistle, sailed yesterday on the Anchor steamship City of Rome.

The Baltimores won a game from the NewYorks on the Polo Grounds yesterday. On account of the cool weather there was a poor crowd in attendance. Empty benches did not tend to stimulate the contestants, and they played a spiritless game.

Capt. Donald Kerr, navigator of the Thistle, Second Mate McKenzie, William Cral Quartermaster; Alexander Hill, chief cook, and Archie McNicoll, his assistant, bade good-bye to their Scotch friends in this city at the Caledonian Club rooms in Horatio-street last night, and the club made the evening as merry an occasion as the heart of man could desire.

The sort of competition that is generally followed by a cut-rate war among the great trunk lines of the country is at present raging among some of the leading dry goods houses of the city, and a smashing of prices is the order of the day.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12.--Upon the reassembling of the United States Supreme Court to-day Chiut-Justice Waite announced that the Court had decided to grant the writs of habeas corpus in the cases of Attorney-General Ayres and two Commonwealth's Attorneys of Virginia, who are now in prison in Richmond for disregarding the orders of Judge Bond in the coupon crusher litigation.

Mr. George Munson, Secretary of the St. Louis Browns, was in this city yesterday arranging for the games to be played at Washington Park, in Brooklyn, to-morrow and at the Polo Grounds on Saturday between the Detroit and St. Louis Clubs for the world's championship. Secretary Munson is confident in the ability of the Browns to cope successfully with the Detroits in the series of games.

COUNCIL BLUFFS, Iowa, Oct. 12.--The southward flight of the Presidential party began at Minneapolis at 8:10 last evening. The two ladies of the party retired early, but the President and the male members of the escort sat for a couple of hours smoking their cigars and comparing experiences.

At the annual meeting of the shareholders of the Western Union Telegraph Company yesterday all the members of the old Board of Direotors were re-elected, the vacancy caused by the death of Robert Lenox Kennedy being filled by the election of Charles Lanier, of Winslow, Lanier Co.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 12.--The announcement that Gov. Lounsbury will not be here on Thursday to receive Gov. Davis of Rhode Island, who is to be the guest of the Putnam Phalanx with the Newport Artillery, is received with marked dissatisfaction.

Between 120 and 150 gentlemen are expected to sit down to the dinner given in honor of Gen. Paine and Designer Burgess at Delmonico's to-night. Commodore Gerry will make a speech and introduce the other speakers, among whom will be Gen. Paine, Mr. Burgess, Goorge L. Schuyler, and Alexander Hamilton. Lander's orchestra and a male quartet will furnish music.
Grace Church, Brooklyn, was the scene of a brilliant wedding last evening. Miss Alice Mande Vail, daughter of the late William M. Vail, was the bride and Mr. Frederick Conner Dexter the groom.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 12.--For 29 years the name of Garrett has been at the head of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad. To-day, by the resignation of Robert Garrett, it disappeared.
Only a little while ago there was much parading of a forty-seven-million-dollar surplus that the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad had. Yesterday that company was obliged to quit paying dividends.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 12.--R.S. Hicks, the Cashier of the Stafford National Bank, who was arrested at Stafford Springs this afternoon charged with defalcation, is the Treasurer of the Stafford Savings Bank, which will probably be wrecked by Cashier Hicks's downfall.
BERLIN, Oct. 12.--In an interview to-day Dr. Mackenzie said: "The Crown Prince's general health is good, but unhappily there are certain symptoms which cause anxiety."
UTICA, N.Y., Oct. 12.--The first snow of the season here fell at 10:30 o'clock to-day.

OMAHA, Neb., Oct. 12.--The Democratic State Convention to-day nominated Thomas O'Day, of Antelope County, for Justice of the Supreme Court, and Dr. Slicker, of Hitchcock County, and Fred L. Harris for Regents of the State University. The convention in its platform indorsed President Cleveland's Administration, reaffirmed the principles of the national platform of 1884, ...

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 12.--The Grand Lodge of the State of Missouri, A.F. and A.M., is in session still, and great interest centres in the action on the law relenting saloon keepers from the order. The charter of the Naphtall Lodge of this city was recently arrested because it refused to eject the liquor men.

The house of Miss Helen Dauvray, 49 Park-avenue, was besieged all day yesterday by people curious to know where and how the actress had been married to John M. Ward, ex-Captain of the New-York baseball team.

Dr. Henri Nachtel, of Paris, returned from Newport Tuesday, where he had gone to lay his benevolent project of establishing in Paris an ambulance system, such as is in use in this country, before Minister Roustan, for the purpose of enlisting his co-operation.

The 4-year-old daughter of Nathan Levi, of 60 Prince-street, Newark, N.J., while playing around a bonfire in the street last night, was fatally burned. In attempting to save her child the mother was badly burned.

PARIS, Oct. 1.1--The Journal des Debats says that France does not desire to take possession of Morocco, or to do injury to the material interests of Spain. Moorish waters will soon witness an assembling of men-of-war of all countries, in which even America will be represented. The precise object of this assemblage, the Journal contiuues, is unknown, and it is possible that the participants are animated by widely divergent intentions.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12.--The following changes in the duties and stations of officers of the Corps of Engineers have been ordered: Capt. W.I Fisk has been relieved from duty in the office of the Chief of Engineers and ordered to New-Orleans, relieving Major William H. Heur, who is ordered to San Francisco, relieving Capt. A.H. Payson. Cadet Wallace R. Stokes has resigned to take effect Oct. 20.

The entire second brigade, consisting of the Twenty-third, Fourteenth, Forty-seventh, Thirty-second, and Thirteenth Regiments, and the Third Battery of Brooklyn, and the Seventeenth Separate Company of Infantry, Flushing, was drawn up in line on the Prospect Park parade ground at 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon. Gen. McLeer was in command. Shortly after that hour Gov. Hill and his staff arrived, and ...
While nominations for the Senate and Assembly have been going on for some time in other parts of the State, the conventions are yet to be held in this city.

More money will be needed for the support of New-York's public schools for 1888 than was spent upon them in 1887. The sum obtained for the purpose last year by the Board of Education from the Board of Estimate and Apportionment was $3,994,088.

BELFAST, Oct. 12.--Mr. Chamberlain adrressed an audience of 4,500 persons in Ulster Hall to-night. He said he knew the condition of the poor tenants of Donegal. It was a subject of earnest thought, and he hoped that before he left Ulster he would find a solution of the question. [Cheers.]

ALBANY, Oct. 12.--The case of Quarantine Commissioner Thomas C. Platt was advanced one step to-day. Judge Learned, of the Supreme Court, heard the arguments on the demurrer to Attorney-General O'Brien's action to oust him from office, and will probably render a decision in a few days.
Gateshead is a thriving town in England, opposite Newcastle-on-Tyne, and every year its people pay into the public treasury a lot of money for Government support.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 12.--Philadelphia, 3; Athletic, 3. Game was called at the end of the tenth inning on account of darkness. Batteries-- Buffinton and Clements; Seward and Robinson, Base hits--Philadelphia, 11; Athletic 14. Errors-- Philadelphia, 7; Athletic, 3.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 12.--The Princeton football eleven to-day defeated Rutgers by a larger score than the latter obtained against Stevens on Saturday. The Princeton men played their strongest team, and secured 30 points, while Rutgers failed to score. The game was second in the State championship series.

FAIRMOUNT, Ill., Oct. 12.--There is now on file in the Circuit Clerk's office of this county legal documents pertaining to a small lot in the village of Indianola, which were partly written by Abraham Lincoln in May, 1856, and depositions of witnesses filed in another legal controversy over the same property were written by Grover Cleveland in Buffalo, N.Y., Sept. 29, 1879.

The Governors of the Stock Exchange de- voted themselves yesterday afternoon to the case of John J. Gould, of the suspended firm of Gould Henry, and recommitted the case to the Committee on Insolvency to make a further investigation.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 12.--Drafts--Sight, 17 cents; telegraphic, 30 cents.

Ex-Gov. Abbett, of New-Jersey, in the role of an Anarchy champion, and ex-Senator Charles H. Winfield as the opponent of the redrag idea and defender of law and order, made a spectacle in the Hudson County Court House yesterday that will not soon be forgotten.

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 12.--All officers of the naval brigade were ordered to be present this morning to hear the explanation of the manaeuvres for to-morrow's sham battle by Major Livormore.

BRIDGEPORT, Oct. 12.--An independent appraisal of the Sharps rifle factory property in this city, on which the Continental Life Insurance Company, of Hartford, holds a mortgage for $212,000, has been made under the authority of State Treasurer Warner.
SIMLA, Oct. 12.--According to the official reports there were 30,780 fatal cases of cholera in the northwest provinces during the month of August.

Both the Rev. C.W. Millen, Pastor of the Washington-Street Methodist Episcopal Church, Brooklyn, who is being examined by a committee of ministers on a charge of improper conduct, and his wife were witnesses at yesterday's session.

Mr. William P. Moore announces the sales at his gallery, 290 Fifth-avenue, on Saturday next, of Hester Brothers' collection of porcelains, ivories, and Oriental art objects. This collection is said to contain the finest specimens of jades ever shown. On Nov. 12 Mr. Moore will sell the collection of American paintings amd bric-a-brac belonging to Mr. J.M. Burt, of Brooklyn, and on Nov. 19 the Durand-Ruel collection of French impressionist pictures.

Dr. Joseph Parker lectured last night in Association Hall, Brooklyn, his subject being "Clocks and Watches." The lecture was enjoyed by the small audience present, especially as the doctor was unrestrained in his flights of oratory and delivered his lecture in an easy manner. His "Clocks and Watches" represented the kinds of men found in this world, and the ...

Blackwell's Island, of which any good thing can be no more reasonably expected than was expected of Nazareth of old, yesterday showed a remarkable facility for producing nurses of a high order of excellence and of engaging manners and attractive appearance.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 12.--William Langtry, alias "Hop-up" Langtry, and Charles Johnson, alias James Johnson, who participated in the Jersey City Post Office robbery on the night of Feb. 1 last, went to State Prison to-day for four years and four months.

The fair for the benefit of Canton Washington, No. 11, of the Patriarchs Militant, the military branch of the Oddfellows, was opened last evening at the lodge rooms, Fifty-secondstreet and Seventh-avenue. Several of the grand encampment officers of the order were present, being escorted from the headquarters on Union-square by 120 of the Patriarchs from Brooklyn, Yonkers, and New-Rrunswick, N.J., as well as from the Canton Washington.
The American Jockey Club will give an extra day's racing at Jerome Park to-morrow, the programme for which is as follows:

OTTAWA, Oct. 12.--The Government has received information of the grounds of the appeal to be made to the Supreme Court of the United States from the judgment of the United States District Court in Alaska, confiscating the British schooner W.P. Sayward for hunting and sealing in Behring Sea.

Mayor Haynes's plurality for re-election to the Mayoralty of Newark is about 1,300. The Labor vote cast for the Rev. Hugh O. Pentecost was a surprise because of its smallness, and the Law and Order Prohibition vote cast for exAlderman William E. Pine was a surprise because of its largeness.

A cable from London announces the death from consumption of the veteran English jockey, George Fordham. Veteran English turfmen always considered Fordham to be the greatest jockey that ever sported silk, not excepting Archer. He was born in 1838 and won his first notable race with Hampton at the Brighton track in 1857.

The new South provided the leading speakers at the Prohibition mass meeting at Cooper Union last night. They were Col. R.S. Cheves, of Kentucky, who was down on the programme, and Sam Small, of Georgia, who proved none the less welcome because he was not.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 13.--The intercollegiate lawn tennis tournament was practically concluded today, and the Harvard players have come out of it with flying colors, while Yale has made but a poor showing. A big crowd assembled at the New-Haven Lawn Club's courts to-day to watch the play, which was, as a rule, very good tennis.

LONDON, Oct. 13.--An enthusiastic crowd welcomed Mr. Chamberlain upon his arrival at Ballymena, Ireland, to day. He made a speech, in which he said that his progress had confirmed his impression that the people were loyal and contented, and that they would resist to the uttermost any attempt to sever the connection between Ireland and Great Britain.

Miss Isabel Frances Morris, daughter of Mr. John A. Morris, owner of the Louisiana State Lottery, was married yesterday at noon in the West Presbyterian Church, in Forty-secondstreet, to Mr. Thurlow Weed Barnes, grandson of Thurlow Weed.
CINCINNATI, Oct. 13.--The attendance at Latonia to-day was the largest of the Fall meeting. The races were run off with the following results:
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13.--The Secretary of the Interior to-day received a telegraphic report from Special Agent Howard on the situation at the Crow agency in Montana. The agent says:
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 13.--In the United States Circuit Court to-day the Farmers' Loan and Trust Company of New-York filed a bill in equity to foreclose the mortgage on the Forest Park and Central Railway.

NYACK, Oct. 13.--Quiet a sensation was caused in the village of Haverstraw a day or two ago by the arrest of a young man who forged the name of Uriah F. Washburn, President of the People's Bank, of that village, and attempted to pass three checks.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 13.--In the Court of Appeals to-day, the Hon. W.C. Ruger, Chief-Justice, and associates present, the following causes were argued: No. 494--John Lilly, appellant, vs. The New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad, respondent--Argued by S.D. Morris for appellant, B. F. Tracy for respondent.

The strike of the printers was supplemented yesterday by a lock-out at the office of John Polhemus, who had acceded to the demands of Typographical Union No. 6, but who declared that the printers sought to impose fresh terms upon him. So he went over to the office of the Typothetae and joined that association. He employed about 100 men.
Mr. Robarts Harper will give the first of his series of illustrated lectures at Niblo's next Sunday night. The title is "The Three Jubilees."

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 13.--To follow out the problem proposed it must be imagined that Newporters were excited this morning to hear that the North Atlantic squadron had succeeded in forcing its way through the Dutch Island Passage and was safe at anchor to the eastward of the north point of Conanicut Island.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 13.--In the Western District Republican Convention, at Pawtucket, today, Warren O. Arnold was nominated for Congress.

Abraham Suydam, the attorney for Mrs. Emma Lee Hudson, the confidence woman of many aliases, applied yesterday, in the Tombs Police Court, for the discharge of his client on the ground that there was no evidence to show that she was net Mrs. C.J. Lawrence.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Oct. 13.--The Cleveland Drug Company, doing a wholesale business at 149 Water-street, made an assignment to-day. The assets are said to be $60,000 and the liabilities $50,000.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Oct. 13.--There is considerable unfavorable comment in and around the village of Bath over the decision of the Court of Appeals depriving the soldiers of the privilege of voting in that place.

The fifth game in the world's championship series will take place to-day at Washington Park, Brooklyn. The Detroit and St. Louis Clubs are champions of their respective associations, and in these grand world's championship contests the two teams are pitted against each other, battling for the honors which are the highest to be attained in the national game.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., Oct. 13.--The schooner Thomas L. Tarr, which sailed from here Aug. 19 on a fishing voyage with a crew of 14 men has been given up for lost, with all on board. She was last seen at anchor on Sept. 3, the day of the disastrous hurricane on the Banks, and has not been heard from since.

"Is it not significant," asks our young contemporary, the Evening World, "that JAMES G. BLAINE should lead HENRY GEORGE six votes as first choice for President at the Anti-Poverty Fair, and that Gov. HILL should beat President CLEVELAND 150 to 25?"

The 1,545 members of the Tammany General Committee met lastevening, under the title of the Tammany County Convention, and went through the preliminaries of the "deal" that has been made with the County Democracy organization.
CHICAGO, Oct. 13.--The Central Traffic Association to-day adopted these recommendations of a committee recently appointed to devise means for securing the restoration of export freight rates:

PITTSBURG, Penn., Oct. 13.--Detroit won the fourth game of the world's championship series played here to-day. Three thousand people were present. The victory was an easy one for the League champions, who nevertheless played a wonderful game, shutting St. Louis out.
During September the gross earnings of the Pittsburg and Western Railway Company amounted to $186,755.14, against $151,736.32 in September, 1886.

The Columbia Freshmen yesterday morning appeared at college all grouped about one cane, which they intended to defend against any possible aggressions by the Sophomores. The latter, however, kept to their intention of discoutinuing rushing, and the Freshmen sheepishly retired.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Oct. 13.--Several gentlemen of wealth and business standing are alarmed over a report that an investigation is likely to be made of the connection of the Third National Bank with the Handy wheat deal, by which about $2,000,000 was won in Chicago by Cincinnatians a few years ago.

Perfect weather, a large attendance, an excellent track, faultless starting, no delays, no accidents, full fields, and good horses made yesterday one of the most pleasurable racing days in the history of Jerome Park.

MONTREAL, Oct. 13.--A man named Damase Desormiers Ditaasson, who called himself a priest, was sentenced at the last session of the Court of Queen's Bench to 23 months' imprisonment and to receive 20 lashes for having committed an indecent assault on a young girl.

CHICAGO, Oct. 13.--The Sheriff has almost entirely shut down on the admission of casual visitors to the jail, and in consequence none but their regular callers are present during the exercise hour of the Anarchists.

The German-American Independent citizens held their County--Convention last night at Beothoven Hall. There were 380 delegates present. Charles E. Wondt was made permanent Chairman; Martin Fuerst, Adolph Widt, ...

Paying Teller Frank Kain, of the Sub-Treasury, in looking over the checks from the Clearing House, had his attention arrested by three bearing the name of John T. Rankin, United States Marshal at San Antonio, Texas.

The thirteenth annual examination of the Nautical School was held yesterday on the schoolship St. Mary's, anchored in the East River below Fulton Ferry. Capts. George W. Brown, Joseph P. Hamilton, and L. Mackay were the examining board.

When Scotchman Cummings came to this country, under contract, to conduct a dairy farm, or something of the kind, in Kentucky, and was not permitted to remain here, but was promptly shipped back to Scotland because the law labeled him "contract labor," his countrymen who had settled here before such a law was thought of were very wroth.

STILLWATER, Minn., Oct. 13.--Frank Landers, alias Wilbur F. James, the notorious diamond swindler and confidence man, who swindled many diamond dealers and others of St. Paul and who made his escape from the penitentiary last night, has a record which for audacity and cunning has never been equaled in the annals of criminal history.

CHICAGO, Oct. 13.--J.B. Owens, the Pacific express messenger running from St. Louis to Texarkana, who was arrested here on Sunday charged with stealing $26,000 from the company, has made a confession to W.A. Pinkerton. After taking the money at Texarkana he went to Dallas, and thence to St. Louis, burying the money near the outskirts of that city.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13.--James H. McGindley was arrested by Special Examiner Jacobs, of the Pension Bureau, on Sept. 30 on a charge of forgery and other frauds in connection with pension claims. On the same day he was brought before Commissioner A.J. Williams at Cleveland, Ohio, where he waived a hearing, ...

President Bayles, of the Board of Health, after a conference with Health Officer Smith in relation to the quarantined passengers of the Alesia, said yesterday that there was scarcely a possibility of cholera being brought to the city by these passengers.

According to the most excellent authority speculation over the successorship to the seat on the bench of the United States Supreme Court made vacant by the death of Justice Woods, of Louisiana, may as well end, for L.Q. C. Lamar, Secretary of the Interior, has been selected for the place.

Port Chester took a holiday yesterday, and its houses were profusely decorated. Every factory was closed and nearly all places of business. It was the fiftieth birthday of the village.

The debate between Messrs. Henry George and S.E. Shevitch over the land tax theory has been postponed until Oct. 23.

VINCENNES, Ind., Oct. 13.--Twenty-five hundred to 3,000 miners are out on strike in Southern Indiana, and a coal famine is upon us. One thousand miners or more are out in the Daviess County coal mines, and they propose to stray out, and will not listen to any compromise. The companies are equally stubborn, and the fight promises to be a long, warm, and bitter one.

The Thirteen Club held its usual ghastly revel for this month, last evening, at Morelli's, West Twenty-eighth-street. Judge McAdam presided over the weird gathering, and among those present were Col. George W. Paschal of Texas: Capt. William Fowler, Judge Samuel Jones, B.W. Ellison, J. S. Hood, N.W. Raphael, L.M. Sheldon. Jr., and C.W. Albertus. It was the club's sixty-ninth repast.
HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Oct. 13.--The cable steamer Britannia arrived here to-day from London. She is to transfer the Direct Cable Company's plant from Torbay to Halifax and land the cable here.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13.--The leave of absence of First Lieut. R.H. Young, Fourth Infantry, has been extended until further orders. First Lieut. Arthur Murray, First Artillery, has been detailed as Acting Judge-Advocate of the Department of the Missouri, relieving Second Lieut. R.G. Hill, ...
OTTAWA, Oct. 13.--Sir Charles Tupper, Minister of Finance and High Commissioner to England was chosen this afternoon as Canada's representative at the coming Fishing Convention.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Oct. 13.--The body of Miss Mary Rice, burned to death, was found today in the ruins of the destroyed part of the insane asylum. This makes the number of victims of the fire seven, all of them patients except Miss Rice, who had been employed in the institution as seamstress some years.

George H. Jessup and Horace Townsend have been commissioned by Mrs. Langtry to write a new play for her, the subject of which she has suggested herself. A synopsis of the plot was read to the lady early this week, and she expressed herself as fully satisfied with it.

The Sophomores of Princeton College, following the usual Fall custom, have issued a proclamation to the Freshmen instructing them in their duties. The poor youths who have recently entered the college are told of their various weaknesses in being east forth from their nurseries a brood of helpless innocents.

CHICAGO, Oct. 13.--The best counterfeit fivedollar gold piece ever seen in the Government building was received there yesterday from Cuba, Ill., coming as part of the Postmaster's receipts from that point. It was perfect in form, size, and weight, and was marked as having been coined in 1855. Something about its appearance influenced Superintendent Schfossman to doubt its genuineness, though others in the building were confident it was "straight."

The giving of testimony and closing addresses of counsel, in the trial of Policeman Edward Hahn for the murder of Capt. Jack Hussey, were finished yesterday. Hahn, who the day before had told his version of the killing, was closely questioned by his counsel as to the motive which prompted the firing of the fatal shot.

JACKSON, Miss, Oct. 13.--John Wilson, a farmer living at Pachola, in Clark County, has in the past few months suffered grievously at the hands of an unknown but merciless enemy. His barn, stables, cows, horses, and provender have been burned and his dwelling narrowly escaped the torch of the incendiary.
WARSAW DEPOT, N.Y., Oct. 13.--Mr. Robert E. Miller was married last evening to Miss Belle H. Nassau, in the Presbyterian Church, by the Rev. Dr. Nassau, father of the bride.

PORTLAND, Me., Oct. 13.--David Stain and Oliver Cromwell Smith, who are charged with the murder of Cashier Barron, of the Dexter, (Me.) Bank nine years ago, passed through here to-day on the way to Dexter under charge of Sheriff Mitchell.

NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 13.--This morning at 9 o'clock the residents in the immediate vicinity of Margaret-place were startled by the report that a dynamiter was in the park and intended to blow up the Margaret Statue. They looked out of windows and doors and saw at the statue a white man digging a hole.
UTICA, Oct. 13.--George F. Berry, of Oneida, Madison County, has been nominated by the Democrats of Madison, Herkimer, and Otsego (Twentythird) Districts for State Senator.

MADRID, Oct. 13.--The Queen Regent has signed a decree authorizing the construction of six ironclads of 7,000 tons each, which shall be capable of attaining a speed of from 16 to 20 miles an hour; also 4 large and 60 small torpedo boats.
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 13.--Russell Brown, who six years ago was sentenced from this city for the murder of his grandmother. Mrs. Davis, escaped from the penitentiary at Jefferson City yesterday.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 14.--Diphtheria has made its appearance in this city and threatens to make headway in the lower wards. Two deaths are reported today. In one family three deaths occurred from the same disease this week. Prompt measures are being taken to prevent its spread.

PARIS, Oct. 4.--As the Raon incident will have been settled long before any letter on the matter can reach America, all that is necessary to say about it is that the French press in general was remarkably temperate and throughout seconded the Government's efforts to reassure the public.
ALBANY, Oct. 15.--Bank Superintendent Willis S. Paine has authorized the Bank of Chateaugay to transact a general banking business under the State laws, with paid-up capital of $25,000.

MONTREAL, Oct. 15.--A leading constitutional lawyer has given his opinion that the three-hundred-thousand-dollar loan asked for by the Manitoba Government for the Red River Railway is illegal, and, acting upon his advice, the banks here have refused to advance any money. The rails for the road are still lying on the wharf here waiting the payment of the money due on them.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Oct. 15.--The Republican Judicial Convention of the Sixth District to nominate two candidates for Supreme Court Justices to succeed the Hon. Douglas Boardman and the Hon. Francis R. Gilbert, adjourned at 12:30 o'clock today for a recess until 4 P.M. on Monday.

PHELPS, N.Y., Oct. 15.--Prof. Brooks observed the Olbers-Brooks comet this morning. It is now in constellation coma Berinices in the eastern morning sky, and may be easily observed with small telescopes, being now at its brightest. The comet was nearest to the earth four days ago, and will return to perihelion in 72 years.

The season for revolver practice has opened with new and novel features in revolver shooting. One of them is the Wimbledon target. This target was used in the recent revolver matches of the National Rifle Association of Great Britain to test the quickness, as well as the accuracy, of the marksmen.

Louis Kallenbach, 15 years old, was walking on the trestle work of the Rapid Transit Railroad, at Stepleton, yesterday, when he saw a train approaching. In endeavoring to get out of the way his leg was caught and held so that he could not move. In his frantic endeavors to free the limb he fractured it badly. FOXBURG, Penn., Oct.17.--A skiff containing six men was capsized in the Allegheny River to-day, and two brothers, J. and H. Neville, were drowned. The others managed to keep up until rescued. LANCASTER, Penn., Oct. 18.--Samuel Vollrath, an employe of the Pennsylvania Railroad, aged 21 years, was killed at this place this morning. WASHINGTON, Oct. 20.--The St. Louis-Detroit combination now playing for the world's championship arrived in this city this morning to play the tenth game of the series. They met a heavy rain, however, which rendered the grounds unfit for play, and the game was postponed until to-morrow morning. After the game here they will go to Baltimore and play there in the afternoon.

READING, Penn., Oct. 21.--Martin Stenson, of Frackville, Schuyikill County, was to-day committed to jail, charge with causing the death of his wife. The couple were seen fighting in their yard last evening, and the woman ran into the house, followed by her husband. Subsequently the neighbors saw Mrs. Stenson fall from the second story window. She struck the fence and was impaled through the neck on one of the pickets, death resulting instantly.

CONCORD, N.H., Oct. 21.--The Senate and House this forenoon voted to reconsider the vote for final adjournment at noon to-day. The date of final adjournment is thus rendered uncertain.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 21.--The ship Invincible arrived in port from New-York to-day. She was 182 days out, and, not having been spoken during her long voyage, caused some uneasiness. She had a rough time at Cape Horn, Capt. Strickland reporting the worst weather he had ever experienced.

AUSTIN, Texas, Oct. 21.--The following is the assessed value of stock in Texas, as shown by the last assessment now on file in the Controller's office: Horses and mules, 1,193,522 head; value, $32,221,771. Cattle, 6,741,964 head; value, $48,735,614. The decrease in value of cattle from last year is about $6,000,000.

SCITUATE, Mass, Oct. 21.--A large vessel, probably a three-masted schooner, is at anchor off Fourth Cliff with only her foremast standing. A very heavy sea is running, and she is pitching violently. Her main and mizzen masts are gone close to the deck, and her rail appears to be badly smashed.

Rev. Dr. R. Heber Newton, looking quite jaunty in a gray suit and light felt hat, reached home on the Adriatic yesterday. He went away last April in search of rest, and had a somewhat hard time for one on that mission. The voyage over by the Italian line was one of the worst he ever had.

TALLULAH, La., Oct. 21. -- Andrew Flaming, colored, was hanged here to-day for the murder of Demp Benyon. The execution took place within the prison inclosure. CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Oct. 21.--A collision occurred on the Nashville and chattanooga Railroad near the Tennessee and Alabama line at an early hour this morning between two freight trains. J. W. Jones and A.W. Wallace were instantly killed. Charles, Johnson was buried under the debris for half an hour, bat was taken out alive, with one leg broken. The engineer and fireman of both trains jumped and escaped uninjured.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Oct. 21.--A Tampa dispatch reports 13 now cases and 3 deaths. The weather is cooler, but the fever is not abating. If refugees continue to return quarantine will be declared in self-defense. The hospital is now ready. The Mayor is having the city thoroughly cleaned. The Executive Committee of the City Council have negotiated a loan for sanitary and poor purposes. Jacksonville to-day raised over $600 for the relief of the Tampa sufferers.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 1.--Ninety-two of the 167 towns in this State voted "No license" at the October election; 72 voted in favor of license, and three remain to be heard from. In the cities, especially in Hartford, there was a large increase in the no license vote.

PERU, Ind., Oct, 24.--The Pan Handle and Lake Erie and Western are again at war at Kokomo over the switch track into the glass works. The land was originally deeded to the Peru Railway and purchased by the Lake Erie.

Mme. Modjeska received the news of the death of her mother, in Poland, after leaving the stage of the Omaha Opera House last Saturday night, on which she had played Juliet. Pulsifer and Andrews, the remaining partners of the firm of R.M. Pulsifer Co. Mr. Haskell has been connected with the Herald for 28 years, as reporter, editor, and proprietor.

BOSTON, Oct. 26.--The Dartmouth College football eleven were defeated this afternoon by the team from the Institute of Technology by a score of 24 to 13. The game was characterized by brisk, steady playing throughout. Kelly, of Harvard, was referee.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Oct. 26.--The concluding game of the world's championship series was placed here to-day before 800 people. The weather was cold, and the players were ready to quit at the conclusion of the sixth inning.

CONCORD, N.H., Oct. 26.--In the House this afternoon the bill ratifying and confirming the lease of the Manchester and Lawrence Railroad to the Boston and Maine Railroad for 50 years was passed under suspension of the rules. The bill containing amendments regarding railroad fares was passed without debate under suspension of the rules.

CHICAGO, Oct. 26.--The revised handicaps for the Chicago cushion-carrom billiard tournament, to begin Nov. 5, were announced to-day as having been finally agreed upon, as follows: Schaefer and Slosson, 200 points; Carter, 170; Gallagher and Catton, 160; Maggiolia and Anson, 150; Hatley, 115, and Moulds, Thatcher, Ives, Mathews, Day, Donovan, and Mullen, 110 each. Entries close Oct. 23.

Judge Coxe, in the United States Circuit Court yesterday, granted an order dismissing the suit of the Oregon and Transcontinental Railroad Company against the Northern Pacific Railroad Company, and allowing the St. Paul and Northern Pacific Railroad Company to withdraw their demurrer and answer.

LONDON, Oct. 26.--This was the third day of the Newmarket Houghton meeting. The race for the Dewhurst Plate was won by three lengths by Sir F. Johnstone's ch. c. Friar's Balsam. Mrs. T. Chaloner's ch. c. Blanton was second, a head in front of Mr. T. Valentine's b.c. Sky Pilot, third. The last betting was 33 to 1 on Friar's Balsam, 100 to 1 against Blanton, and 50 to 1 against Sky Pilet.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 26.--The annual Fall handicap games of the Princeton Athletic Association took place to-day. In spite of the blustering weather it was one of the most successful meetings the association has ever had, there being a large number of entries and a good crowd of spectators.

Among the Passengers of the North German Lloyd steamship Saale, which sailed yesterday for Bremen, were A.H. Willoughby, Dr. Herman Wildermuth, Paul von Amsberg, Col. James Baker, Judge W.H. Davis, Capt. John Breitfeld, Col. C.B. Lamborn, and Prof. George Forbes.

SHREVEPORT, La., Oct. 26.--This town has been greatly excited for the past two days over a violent publication in the Daily Democrat, signed by Charles M.D. Pucketh, and assailing the editor and proprietor of the Daily Times. It was at first expected that an encounter with shotguns would ensue.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 26.--Charles Reilly, who resided at 127 Putnam street, and was a student in the High School here, tried to jump aboard a freight train in the freight yard here this afternoon. He made a miscalculation and fell on the track. His neck was broken and he died almost instantly.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 26.--The accounts of A.M. Way are being examined by committees of the insurance companies and building loan associations he represented, and it is feared that extensive deficiencies will be discovered. Mr. Way is a Mason and Knight of Pythias and a prominent and popular member of other organizations.

The Republicans of Queens County held three conventions in Jamaica yesterday, one for county officers and two for Assemblymen. In the First Assembly District Ernest Lutters, of College Point, had no opponent.

The Westchester County Republicans held three conventions at White Plains yesterday to nominate candidates for office. David Cromwell was nominated for County Treasurer for a fourth term without opposition.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 26.--Considering the exciting campaign preceding it to-day's election for Mayor passed off with unusual quietness. NEWBURG, Oct. 26.--The Democrats of the First Assembly District of Orange County yesterday nominated William F. Cameron, who has declined the nomination. ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 26.-- At a meeting of the Trustees of Cornell University to-day a new Professorship of Horticulture was created in the Department of Agriculture. The $15,000 from the annual appropriation which Congress has given to State colleges founded under the provisions of the Land Grant act will be expended in making improvements in this department.

READING, Penn., Oct. 26.--The Reading Hardware Company, of this city, notified its employes that on and after next pay day their wages would be reduced 10 per cent. When wages were advanced last Spring it was done upon condition that the advance was for six months only. The molders demur and will appoint a committee to adjust the difference.

DAYTON, Ohio, Oct. 26.-- Judge Van Derveer, at Hamilton to-day, decided the case of G. K. Duckworth vs. The Cincinnati, Hamilton and Dayton Railroad Company, granting the injunction as prayed for in the supplemental proceedings against the Directors and deciding in favor of the appointment of a Receiver to take charge of the affairs of the company.

Boston men of wealth who have removed to some small town to save a few dollars in taxes are beginning to see the mistake since a corrupt ring has got possession of the city and placed an over-valuation on their city property in order to lower the rate as a help to continue Democratic misrule. The Democrats held conventions in the three Aldermanic districts of Brooklyn last night and nominated these candidates: First District--John McCarthy, John McGarry, Michael Coffee, and James Kane; Third District--J. Jefferson Black, William McKee, Edward C. Murphy, and Daniel McGrath. The convention in the second District was adjourned.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 26.--The sixth annual national meeting of the Woman's Home Missionary Society of the Methodist Episcopal Church will begin in this city to-morrow. There will be over 200 delegates present from all parts of the United States. The meeting will last a week and will be presided over by Mrs. Rutherford B. Hayes, of Fremont, Ohio. All the delegates are women, and a reception is to be tendered them to-morrow afternoon.

One of the most brilliant weddings of the season took place yesterday morning at the cathedral, when Miss Marie Louise Bruner, daughter of Mrs. K. Bruner Happel, was married to Joseph J. O'Donohue, Jr. Over 1,000 invitations had been issued.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Oct. 27.--Emigration papers to over 50 persons going to the United States to settle have been issued by the American Consul here during the past three days. The majority of the emigrants are farmers, and many take with them thousands of dollars' worth of personal effects.

EAST SAGINAW, Mich., Oct. 27.--The Michigan Salt Association, which controls the market west of Cleveland to the Rocky Mountains, will stop the manufacture of salt from Dec. 1 to April 1 to reduce the large surplus now on the market.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27.--Dave Johnston, the well-known New-York bookmaker, this afternoon purchased the 2-year-old gelding Raceland from Mr. Joseph Ullman, of St. Louis, for $17,000. Raceland is undoubtedly the best colt of the year, as he to-day carried 120 pounds to victory in the Capital Stakes. He ran three quarters of a mile in 1.14, a phenomenal performance.

Minor, Chairman, held a joint meeting to-day, and arranged for a State Convention to be held here Jan. 23 for the purpose of nominating a full State ticket. The primaries will be held on or before Jan. 15.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Oct. 27.--A.J. Graham, editor of the Red Oak Independent, formerly of the Indianola Herald, and later of Beaver City (Neb.) Times, was found dead in his office this evening. He was a member in good standing of the United Workmen.

BOSTON, Mass., Oct. 28.--The Roxbury Gaslight Company is $500 poorer than it was this morning, and the Cashier realizes that he had been taken in by two very adroit swindlers. The office was robbed in the same manner as was the Lechmere Bank at Cambridge several years ago.

PINE HILL, N.Y. Oct. 28.--Farmers in many localities in the Catskill Mountains have lost many sheep of late, one man having no less than four carried away in one week by a daring bruin that was seen making leisurely for the woods with one in its mouth in broad daylight.

PERU, Ind., Oct. 28.--The saloon of Peter Camp, at Russiaville, was blown up with dynamite at 3 o'clock this morning. The building and contents were completely wrecked, as well as a livery stable adjoining, in which a man who slept there was badly injured.

TORONTO, Ontario, Oct. 28.--John Corrigan was arrested to-day charged with having deliberately attempted to murder his 8-year-old stepson, John Clayton, by throwing him into the bay.

One of Jay Gould's intimates gave out this bit of confidential information last night: "Cable rates are to be advanced on Nov. 1. PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 28.--The representatives of the Lehigh and Schuylkill Coal Exchange did not meet to-day to arrange prices for next month, although such meeting was expected to-day.

DAYTON, Ohio, Oct. 28.--The water famine that has prevailed in the two western tiers of Ohio counties and the adjoining territory of Indiana is growing serious, for upon the table lands and extended level stretches away from larger streams cattle are actually suffering and bellowing for drink.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 28.--Charles Hamburg, the fine batter, out fielder, and base runner, has been re-engaged by Buffalo for next season.

D. Keon's hotel on the wharf at Verplanck, N.Y., was entered on Thursday evening by a man who asked for something to eat and a glass of lager. As Mrs. Keon turned her back he grasped her by the throat, opened the money drawer, and attempted to rifle it.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Oct. 28.--Dr. Dawson, Assistant Director of the Geological Survey, who headed the party sent by the Dominion Government to explore the country adjacent to the Alaska boundary, has returned to Victoria.

AUSTIN, Texas, Oct. 28.--J.E. Smith, the express mesenger who recently killed two train robbers near El Paso, was paid $2,000 yesterday by order of Gov. Ross, as a reward for his act. Smith will probably get $3,000 from the express company, and $1,000 from the railroad company, making a total of $5,000.

SHREVEPORT, La., Oct. 28.--The duel between the Shreveport editors is off through the arbitration of mutual friends. The matter has been adjusted and the community is this relieved of the pressure of excitement and danger that has been open to it for the past few days.

PORTLAND, Me., Oct. 28.--The meeting of the Protland fishermen for the purpose of expressing views on the complicated matters to come before the joint conference at Washington will be held before Mr. Putnam returns to the national capital after his return from there this time.

Few indoor political mass meetings ever held in New-York during a municipal campaign could compare either in size, intelligence, or enthusiasm with the meeting held at the Cooper Union last night. The man of wide political acquaintance could see at a glance that it was a citizens' meeting, for side by side sat Republicans and Democrats, and the same sentiments were cheered by both.

This morning there died here Prof. Kirchhoff, the celebrated scientist and discoverer of the spectrum analysis. For some years back he had been ailing, but his end came rather unexpectedly. He was burn at Konigsberg in 1824, and had, therefore, only reached his sixty-third year.

Two sets of theatrical managers are sputtering at each other like roasting apples about the right to use a tank of real water on the stage. Both claim to have letters patent. It is possible to devise a defensible patent, but the words therein will have to be "put very close together." It is a good many years now since a tank of real water was a novelty on the stage.

Mrs. Joseph Wechsler, the wife of the wealthy Brooklyn dry goods merchant, who was injured Friday night by the explosion of an infernal machine, was confined to her bed yesterday. She is not in any immediate danger of death unless lockjaw sets in.
MILWAUKEE, Oct. 29.--A violent northeast gale is now raging on Lake Michigan and steam and sailing vessels are seeking the harbor for shelter. Thus far no disasters have been reported.

In 1882 several piles, coated with various patent anti-teredo coverings, were driven near Mission-street Pier No. 1 for the purpose of testing them. Yesterday Engineer Manson began pulling up the piles in order to see the result of the experiments.

More pleasant reading for drinkers of Schuylkill water. A large tract of low land on the western bank of the Fairmount pool is being filled in with all sorts of nasty and disease-breeding refuse. Prince Bismarck is still as obstinate as ever in his refusal to read any German book or document not written in the ordinary Gothic characters, and so far every effort has failed to convince him that the introduction of Latin characters into schools and offices would be a great saving of both time and eyesight.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., Oct. 29.--The Right Rev. Bishop Dwenger, of this Catholic diocese, is alarmingly ill, and his immediate engagements in a number of places have been canceled and will be filled by Bishop Bademacher.

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 29.--Some interesting experiments were conducted during the week at Rose Island by officers from the torpedo station, with the fuse and nitro-glycerine shell, on the plan proposed by Dark, the Russian inventor, which gave fairly satisfactory results, which will lead to still further experiments in the same direction.

A recent novel invention that is winning favor among women and those that cater to them is of wired ribbon. In making bows, especially for millinery, them has been much trouble in getting the material to stand as upright a was desired, concealed wire a being necessary. Now the wire is woven in the ribbon and is more adaptable than it is in any other way.

One of the stockholders of the Standard Gas Company yesterday confirmed President Andrew's statement to a TIMES reporter that the reports of trouble existing in the company had grown out of a misunderstanding about a forty-thousand-dollar note given to Pittsburg manufacturers of iron pipe.

ATLANTA, Ga,., Oct. 29.--The Rev. Dr. Hornady, one of the leading Baptist clergymen of the city, created a sensation to-day by de claring his opposition to prohibition. He Charactorizes the policy as being opposed to the Bible, and denounces the participation of preachers in political campaigns.

The Prime Minister of Italy, who lately gained such laurels in his own country and in Germany by his visit to Friedrichsruhe, is doubly fortunate, since he has just won also the thanks of the French Government for his successful efforts in behalf of the Suez negotiations.
The Rev. Dr. Joseph H. Price, who was for many years Rector of St. Stephen's Protestent Episcopal Church, died at his apartments in the Ashland House yesterday, after an illness of about a week.

Dr. Elliott Coues, the well-known ornithologist of Washington, was married to Mrs. Mary Emily Bates, of Philadelphia, at the Hotel Vendome, in this city, yesterday. The wedding was in the parlors in the presence of a number of relatives and friends. The Rev. Dr. E.E. Hale officiated.

CUMBERLAND, Md., Oct. 29.--Late Thursday night the jury in the case of Henry J. Spencer, charged with killing W. Scott Dawson, returned a verdict of murder in the first degree. The affair occurred last July. It was caused by a wrong committed eight years before by Dawson upon a young girl who afterward became Spencer's wife.

Paris, Oct. 29.--The whole political situation has changed within a week sharply and for the worse. Last Saturday it looked as if the attempt to injuriously mix M. Wilson up with the decoration scandal had failed--at least to those who are not implacable in their dislike of the man.
The outlook for the stamping out of Asiatic cholera at the Quarantine islands is a very hopeful one, notwithstanding the inexperienced management and criminal neglect of the Commissioners.

The Chief of Police of St. Catharines, Ontario, informed Inspector Byrnes on Friday that Mordaunt Burtch, a law student in the office of Rykert Ingersoll, had absconded with a draft for $3,860, drawn by the Quebec Bank on the Bank of Toronto, at St. Catharines, of the order of his employers and indorsed by them, and $2,460 in Canadian bills.

MONTREAL, Oct. 29.--The deciding Rugby football match for the provincial championship was played this afternoon between Montreal and McGill College teams on the latter's ground. Health Officer Smith stated yesterday that all of the Alesia's passengers on Hoffman's Island were well. No cleaner immigrants of any nationality ever entered the port, the doctor said. Every article of clothing and baggage belonging to them was clean. Only three of the Alesia'a immigrants remained in the hospital on Swinburne's Island, and these were entirely convalescent.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Oct. 29.--While Jennie Campbell, the adopted daughter of William H. Moore, of Westfield, was preparing Mr. Moore's breakfast this morning her clothing caught fire and she ran terrified into the yard. Before the flames were extinguished she was fatally burned. She was 12 years old.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Oct. 29.--The work of restoring the old Senate House here, in which the first Constitution of the State was framed and signed, is being vigorously prosecuted and by Dec. 15 the historic building will look exactly as it did during the great struggle for American independence.

CARLISLE, Penn. Oct. 31.--A commercial traveler going from Fannettsburg to Roxbury last night, was shot at by a highwayman while crossing the mountains. Search parties are on the mountains, but the robber has not been captured.

Dr. William M. Chamberlain, for many years a well-known and valued physician of this city, died at Summit, N.J., yesterday. He was born in Hanover, N.H., in 1826. His father was a Professor in Dartmouth College, and Dr. Chamberlain was a graduate of Dartmouth both in medecine and in the arts.

GENEVA, Nov. 1.--Travel on the St. Gothard Railway has been interrupted by a landslip near Fluelen.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 1.--At a joint meeting of the Yale Academic and Scientific Freshman classes to-night it was voted to challenge the Harvard Freshmen to a two-mile straightaway eight-oared race at New-London next Summer. Last year Harvard declined to row, but as the sentiment at Harvard, it is thought, favors dropping the Columbia races, it is considered more than probable that Yale's challenge will be accepted.

LONDON, Oct. 9.--I Spent an hour with Cardinal Manning on Friday. We sat in his library, a large room, with shelving running around two sides, filled with rare and antique volumes. The furniture of the room is of the plainest character, and the floors are bare except for two small and worn-out rugs, which appear just like a patch in the centre.

The leaders of the Kings County Democracy were entirely satisfied with the mass meeting held at the Academy of Music, in Brooklyn, last night, so far as numbers and enthusiasm go. They would have been better satisfied, however, had the enthusiasm been less tempestuous at the start and more tempestuous toward the finish.

Katharine Munroe died in London, Enggland, on Oct. 17. She was a born American, and yet was scarcely known in this country. She left this city in 1869 for Milan, Italy, to complete her musical studies.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Nov. 1.--This was the second day of the Charleston carnival, and it has been the most glorious day in the history of this ancient town. The weather is simply perfect. There has not been a cloud in the sky all day, and to-night everything is flooded with the light of a full moon.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 1.--Dan Galanaugh won the boat race with Harry Naglee over the lower Course on the Schuylkill River to-day. It was a novel event, but no race, as Galanaugh was not heavily enough hadicapped.

Miss Cariotta Bordeaux is the soubrette. She is said to have a mind of her own, which she sometimes expresses in emphatic words.

CHICAGO, Nov. 1.--Two hundred and fifty union job printers--over half the whole number in the city--went on strike this morning. Their fight is for a nine-hour day. A member of the strikers' Executive Committee said that several of the largest offices yielded before the hour set for the strike. The employers generally express confidence of victory, and intimate that their main line of action will be to fill their offices with non-union men.

HAVANA, Nov. 1.--The Spanish steamer Panama, from New-York, which was ashore on the Florida coast, has arrived here, having floated Sunday afternoon. All on board are well. WASHINGTON, Nov. 1.--The Naval Board on Coast Defense has nearly completed its report. It has agreed upon a system of defense consisting of monitors supported by auxiliary craft, such as rams, and torpedo boats, and has found that the $2,000,000 appropriated by Congress for this purpose will be sufficient to establish at least one unit of the system.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 5.--James O'Rourke, the ball player, was made an attorney at law and a member of the Connecticut Bar to-day. CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Nov. 5.--Miss Annie Deadrick, great-granddaughter of James W. Deadrick, late Chief-Justice of Tennessee, was burned to death yesterday afternoon at Jonesborough, Tenn. Her father was burning leaves off a lot near the house, when her clothes caught fire and were entirely burned from her body. She suffered excruciating pain for three hours, when death relieved her of her terrible sufferings.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 12.--Official returns from all counties in the State give Hart, (Rep.,) for State Treasurer, a plurality of 44,888, a net Republican gain of 1,372, as compared with the vote for State Treasurer in 1885, and 2,237 as compared with the vote for Governor last year. The official figures in nearly all the counties increased the vote for Hart over the earlier estimates.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 12.--The National Opera closed its season here to-night with a crowded house at the final performance of Nero, and goes to-morrow to Baltimore. BALTIMORE, Nov. 12.--It is learned from reliable sources here that next year the Baltimore Baseball Club will appear before the public as a representative of a new baseball league, to be composed of clubs that represent the Eastern cities.

A trial of a new torpedo boat, the Jan tehikhe, destined for the port of Vladivostock, and constructed at St. Petersburg, has given satisfactory results. The average speed attained during to three hours' trip was slightly over the 19 knots contracted for. A further trial is to be made to determine the quantity of coal and the capacity of the bankers necessary for a voyage of 2,000 knots.

NEWPORT, R.I., Nov. 12.--The relatives of the late Edward F. Northam, formerly of this city, who died in San Francisco a few weeks ago, were made happy to-day and are receiving the congratulations of their friends. The deceased leaves an estate estimated to be worth $1,000,000.
