NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 12.--Five members of the Yale football eleven and six substitutes defeated the Wesleyan on the Yale field to-day in a championship game by the score of 68 to 4. This is the first time that Wesleyan has scored a point against Yale at football.

PARIS, Nov. 12.--Parisians think their extravagance in flowers is unequaled by any other city. This is extremely absurd, for they have no idea whatever of the luxury of floral decoration in New-York. The banking up of fireplace, chimneys or room corners is here unknown.

PHENIXVILLE, Penn., Nov. 12.--Thomas Sigman, a son of Thomas M. Sigman, a well-known citizen of this place, became insane a week ago, and was placed in the asylum. Yesterday his father, who was visiting a friend in Montgomery County, went out in the yard, and, placing the muzzle of a gun against his breast, kicked the trigger. His heart and one side were blown to atoms. He had grieved constantly over his son's affliction.

New-Hampshire was the ninth State to ratify, and her vote completed the number necessary to secure its adoption.

HACKETTSTOWN, N.J., Nov. 12.--The Tillie Smith monument, which arrived last week, was placed in positlon in Evergreens Cometery to-day. MANDAN, Dakota, Nov. 12.--Reports of destructive prairie fires in this vicinity continue to come in. The Riverside Ranch Company has lost 300 tons of hay, and settlers have lost several tons more. Horses, wagons, and buildings have been swept away where they stood in the way of the fire.

BOSTON, Nov. 12.--John Burns, third baseman for the Boston Blues last season, and for two years a member of the Lawrence Club, has been in town since August destitute. A ball for his benefit was advertised for last evening, but Burns left for NewYork during the day, taking the money paid in advance for tickets and an overcoat belonging to one of his benefactors. The ball did not take place.

DUBLIN, Nov. 12.--Mr. O'Brien, who is incarcerated in the Tullamore Jail, and who refused to don the uniform prescribed by the prison regulations, were his own clothes until yesterday. Saturn is morning star, and an interesting object for observation as he approaches the cluster of stars called Prasepe. He rises on the 1st at 10h. 34m. P.M. On the 30th he rises at 8h. 40m. P.M. His diameter on the 1st is 17.4, and he is in the constellation Cancer.

BERLIN, Nov. 13.--A dispatch to the National Zeilung from San Remo says that the Crown Prince is in no immediate danger. The Crown Prince's complaint may last for many years. Dr. Mackenzie is about to leave San Remo but will return in a fortnight, provided no totally different decisions are made in the meantime.

LONDON, Nov. 13.--The scene in Trafalgarsquare to-day has not been equaled since 1866, when the people, asserting the right of public meeting, destroyed the railings around Hyde Park. Four thousand policemen took possession of the approaches to Trafalgar-square at an early hour.

ITHACA, N. Y., Nov. 13.--Considerable feeling is manifested by Cornell students in regard to the recent decree of the Faculty that Thanksgiving vacation should consist of but one day. The students are especially dissatisfied, as the Cornell football team is to play an important game with the Lehigh University team at Eimira on Thanksgiving afternoon and they assert that their vacation will allow them barely time enough to attend the game.

District Assembly No. 49 of the Knights of Labor yesterday appropriated to the lockedout brassworkers the money that it had in its assistance fund. It also decided to levy an assessment of 15 cents per capita on all the members of its locals for the benefit of the brassworkers.
EL PASO, Texas, Nov. 13.--The El Paso and Northwestern Railway and Telegraph Company has just been chartered under the laws of Texas, with a capital stock of $300,000.
Sir Charles Dilke, on his recent visit to Constantinople, did not expect to see the Sultan, and declined to ask for an audience.
CHICAGO, Nov. 13.--The Chicago playhouses felt the great nervous strain of the last week, and paid tribute to the Anarchists with empty seats.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13.--Col. C.G. McCauley has submitted to the Secretary of the Navy his annual report on the Marine Corps. He states that on Oct. 1, 1887, there were 1,893 enlisted men in the corps, 930 of whom were on board ships in commission, and 963 doing duty at the several shore stations.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 13.--War was declared today by the Knights of Labor upon the Lehigh coal operators who are resisting the demands of the striking miners for recognition and higher wages, and on the Lehigh Valley Rraillroad, which is looked upon as the strongest ally of the Lehigh Coal and Navigation Company.

The celebration of the one hundred and first anniversary of the old Bowery Village, now the Seventh-Street Methodist Episcopal, Church, was begun yesterday at the church in Seventh-street, between Second and Third avenues, and will continue throughout the week.

The steamship Germanic, of the White Star Line, which arrives at Quarantine Saturday evening, came up to her dock yesterday morning. Col. Emmons Clark, of the Seventh Regiment, who arrived with his family, was welcomed on the dock by a large delegation of the members of the regiment.
Yesterday Mr. E.J. Leland, the electrician, left at the Natural History rooms on Foster-street, a danguerreotype of Jenny Lind, taken in 1850 in Boston.
LYNCHBURG, Va., Nov. 13.--Intense excitement has prevailed in the coal mines at Pocahontas for a week between the colored and Hungarian miners, which culminated in a riot.

The people who drove on the road yesterday were shocked to hear that Judge Smith was near death's door. He was unable to get down stairs on Friday, and yesterday morning, was too weak to get out of his bed.

A tall man, well dressed in black, who had a large brown mustache and prominent features, entered the office of the Grand Union Hotel at 5:20 o'clock last evening and stepped, quickly and nervously to the register.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, Nov. 13.--About 1 o'clock this morning a frightful accident occurred on the Ohio Southern Railroad near Greenfield. A Mogul engine and eight cars crashed through a bridge over Paint Creek to the rocks 30 feet below. The fireman, Jacob Hill, was no badly injured that he died this afternoon. The engineer was not seriously injured. The engine and cars were wrecked.
There are probably but few New-York residents who have failed to notice and admire two elegant edifices located on the north side of Fifty-seventh-street, between Fifth and Sixth avenues.

Mme. Etelka Gerster, the distinguished songstress, arrived at Sandy Hook yesterday on the French steamer La Bourgogne. She was expected by her manager, Henry E. Abbey, who made an excursion down the Bay to welcome her.

PARIS, Nov. 1.--Signor Crispi was very vague, not to say "shifty," when asked to explain the why and wherefore of his recent visit to Prince Bismarck, at that Turin banquet, to which the Peninsulars gave the importance of a historical event, because in it they see a symptom of the evolution made in Italian politics, of which the direction is passing from Northern into Southern hands.

"Paoli," said Napoleon the Great, "should have followed the fortunes of his General and died with him." That is fidelity. Fidelity is not the same in a southern country, where it is attached to tradition, as in a northern country, where it is attached to the law.

GALVESTON, Texas, Nov. 13.--The New-York Giants arrived here this morning from New-Orleans. During the day they played two exhibition games with local clubs before large crowds. They left this evening for Austin. The weather here is Summerlike.
When Mrs. Langtry appeared before the curtain at the close of her engagement in Torento a number in the audience called for a speech.

LONDON, Nov. 13.--There was no demand for discount during the past week; three months was quoted at 2 and short at 2. On the Stock Exchange there was a fairly active business in foreign securities, owing to the pressure of sales on Continental account. English railway securities were weak, with a downward tendency.
Mr. Irving's Saturday night bill comprised "The Bells" and "Jingle," a comedy play in one act founded on an episode in the adventures of Mr. Pickwick and his friends.

No exhibition will be given by the Salmagundi Club this year. By asking for a "student's card" visitors to the large relieious picture by Munkacsy, at the Twenty-third-Street Tabernacle, can secure entrance for a quarter instead of a half dollar.

BOONTON, N.J., Nov. 13.--Simon Somers, Captain of canalboat No. 608, was murdered last night. Before he died he accused James Van Orden of the crime, and the latter is in custody. Somers's boat drifted into the Morris Canal lock at this place at 8 o'clock last night.

A well-built, active gentleman, known to his friends as M. Paul Blouet and to the world at large as Max O'Rell, landed from the steamship Gernanic yesterday, and grasped the hand of Major Pond, who is to guide him through a lecturing tour that he purposes to make in this country.
Miss Alfreda Chippendale, whose death in England was made known in THE TIME'S cable dispatches yesterday, was a grandniece of President Zachary Taylor on the side of her mother.
NEWPORT, R.I., Nov. 13.--The flagship Richmond leaves to-morrow afternoon for NewYork, having procured ten or a dozen tons of coal from the Ossipee to enable her to steam in and out of port.
Reports were published yesterday that Clara Louise Kellogg, the well-known singer, had married her advance agent and business manager, Carl Strakosch.

The preliminary steps leading to the incorporation of the Dry Goods Credit, Guarantee and Indemnity Company have been taken. Its capital is $1,000,000, in shares of $50 each.

Fifty men employed in the kindling wood factory of Kenneth Co., on Third-street, near the Gowanus Canal, Brooklyn, struck yesterday for an increase in their wages of from 20 and 25 cents to 25 and 30 cents a hundred for bundling wood. The Church Temperance Society began its sixth annual convention with a business meeting yesterday afternoon at Annex Hall, 16 Fourth-avenue. Bishop Scarborough, of NewJersey, presided and made the opening address.

DETROIT, Mich., Nov. 14.--Judge Zeppaniah W. Bunce, of Port Huron, reached the great age of 100 years to-day. He was waited upon by a delegation of his fellow-citizens, who tendered him their congratulations. He was born in Hartford, Conn.

BOSTON, Nov. 14.--In the Chelsea Police Court this morning John Hopper, of Boston, an insurance solicitor for the Mutual Reserve Fund Life Association of New-York, was arraigned for illegally insuring the life of Omar Little, Mr. Little being more than 60 years of age. Mr. Hopper pleaded guilty, and paid a fine of $100 and costs.

OSWEGO, N.Y., Nov. 14.--The Rome, Watertown and Ogdensburg Railroad Company has done away with coal stoves in passenger coaches, and today began heating its cars on the Syracuse branch by steam from the engine.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., Nov. 14.--Saturday afternoon Senator Vance, while riding in a road wagon on a narrow road leading to his residence, near Black Mountain, was thrown out, and, falling on his head, received a cut about three inches long, reaching to the bone.

Dr. Goff was tried yesterday at the Police Court in Stapleton, Staten Island, on a charge of larceny preferred by James McKernan, who testified to the fact that certain articles of furniture had been removed from his residence and ultimately spirited away to New-York by the defendant.

PANAMA, Nov. 6.--It is authoritatively announced that an agreement has been entered into between the British and Chilian Governments for the payment by the latter of $100,000 in gold in settlement of all outstanding claims. This amount, it is understood, will be paid to the British Minister at Santiago, by whom it will be distributed among the claimants who are entitled to be indemnified for losses occasioned by the late war.

BAY CITY, Mich., Nov. 17.--Hargrave Co.'s shingle mill burned early this morning, The night crew of 30 men were at work and all barely escaped by jumping from the windows. Isaac Ackerson was probably fatally burned. Samuel Salon was seriously burned and internally injured by jumping. Lewis Blanchard was injuredt about the head. James Small and Levi Carr each suffers from a broken ankle, caused by jumping. Loss, $10,000; uninsured.

LONDON, Nov. 17.--William Saunders, an ex-member of Parliament, who was arrested last week while addressing a crowd in Trafalgar-square, was arraigned in court to-day. He was charged with disorderly conduct in speaking in Trafalgar-square, and thereby causing a disorderly assemblage.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Nov. 17.--All Wednesday and Thursday Western Union linemen were at work repairing wires along the Harlem Railroad from Chatham to Ghent. At Copake, Boston Corners, and Millerton the obstructions and breakdowns were caused by a heavy snowstorm Tuesday night and Wednesday. Fully five inches of snow fell. A high wind prevailed also, and the snow was piled up on the wires. Some of the lines are not yet working.

EL PASO, Texas, Nov. 17.--The factory of the Union Powder Company, situated seven miles northwest of this place, was blown to atoms this morning. A man named Gulick was mixing about 30 pounds of powder outside of the building, when it exploded, igniting 1,500 pounds of powder inside the building. S.S. Carter, of New-York, President of the company, was in the factory. He was mangled terribly and soon died. Gulick was fatally injured.

DETROIT, Mich., Nov. 20.--The purchase by the Flint and Pere Marquette Railway Company of the Port Huron and Northwestern Road, subject only to ratification by both Boards of Directors, who will meet for that purpose next week, has just been announced.

PEILADELPHIA, Nov. 20.--Manager Richard C. White, who produced a dramatization of H. Rider Haggard's story of "She" at the Broad-Street Theatre, took the 8:12 train from the Broad-Street Station to-night for New-York.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Nov. 20.--The typho-malarial epidemic here continues unabated, but the percentage of mortality is small. There are 60 cases of the disease under treatment in two hospitals, besides a hundred other cases scattered throughout the city. The work of ilushing drains has been nearly concluded.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Nov. 20--Mrs. Harry Weldon, wife of the sporting editor of the Cincinnati Enquirer, was buried at Circleville, Ohio, to-day, while her husband, who is convalescing slowly from an attack of typhoid fever, is lying at his home here unconscious of her death. Mrs. Weldon had nursed her husband back to life, when the fever attacked her and she died yesterday.

LONDON, Nov. 21.--Paris is beginning to show disqulering signs of undue excitement. Outdoor sports will flourish on Thanksgiving Day. Football will be pre-eminent because of the game between Yale and Harvard at the Polo Grounds. Yale's backers are very confident. Aaron Swartz, one of the old residents of the city, died yesterday, suddenly, at his home, 1,990 Lexington-avenue. Although 76 years old Mr. Swartz, who had been in excellent health, arose yesterday in good spirits. He went into the bathroom, and soon after was found there dead.

Atkinson, Postmaster-General of New-Zealand, has cabled instructions that oceanic coast steamers bound for Australia shall leave San Francisco at 9 o'clock on Thursday instead of on Friday afternoon as here tofore. LIMA, Ohio, Nov. 24.--Early this morning the second section of a north-bound freight train on the Cincinnati, Hamilton and Dayton Railroad ran into the first section at Anna Station, 20 miles south of this city. The fireman of one of the sections was killed and 20 freight cars and both engines were wrecked. The loss is fully $60,000.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 24.--Charles A. Kebler, a wealthy and prominent attorney, aged 32 years, residing on Reading road, near Oak-street, committed suicide yesterday by taking laudanum. Mr. Kebler's wife, to whom he was greatly attached, died about five months ago. The law firm of which Mr. Kebler was a member took part in the recent suit to appoint a Receiver of the Cincinnati, Hamilton and Dayton Railroad.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 24.--Pearce Kelly, a prisoner in the Camden City Jail, attempted to blow out his brains to-day. He succeeded in sending a bullet through his head from ear to ear, but the surgeons at the Cooper Hospital hope to save his life.

PARIS, Nov. 26.--The peculiar humor of the Parisian is seen now in one of its most interesting phases. It is curious to note how very quiet everything is. Whether this is the great calm before a coming storm remains to be seen.

LONDON, Nov. 26.--The race for the Manchester November Handicap at Manchester to-day was won by Mr. Somers's 4-year-old Carlton, Mr. J. H. Houldsworth's 3-year-old Sorrento was second and Mr. A. Taylor's 6-Year-old Stourhead third.

PLAINFIELD N.J., Nov. 26.--Miss Emma J. Porter's term as Postmistress of Somerville expires Dec. 17. She is a candidate for reappointment and she has gone to Washington laden with letters and credentials from many of the prominent Democrats in Somerset County.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 26.--Jacques Wissler, who engraved nearly all the plates from which the money and bonds of the Confederate States of America were printed, died last night at his home in Camden, N.J., aged 84 years.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 26.--The American Bank of this city, doing business in the old Penn Bank Building, Wood-street, closed its doors this morning and announced that it would go into liquidation. The capital stock is $200,000. It is said by those in a position to know that the bank will pay all claims against it. The stockholders are individually liable.

A real estate auctioneer, in defending the course of the auctioneers in opposing an increase of the knock-down fees, and thus standing in the way of the abolition of sham sales, writes to THE TIMES that, in his opinion, auctioneers do not care to make sham sales, as they do not yield commissions.

NYACK, N.Y., Nov. 26,--An unprecedentedly heavy fog settled upon this region to-day. The ferrybeat between this place and Tarrytown was compelled to suspend its trips this afternoon, and the steamer Chrystenath, which runs between Peekskid and New-York, was only able to get down the river a few miles from her starting,point this morning and then returned to her moorings.

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 26.--By a majority of about 1,000 this city to-day voted in favor of licensing liquor saloons. Fulton County also voted against, prohibition, and the men and women who for a month past have labored so earnestly in favor of prohibition are very much downcast to night.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 26.--Charles A. Gillig, of the American Exchange, London, registered at the Genesee to-day. In conversation Mr. Gillig stated that his present visit to the United States was for the purpose of perfecting the necessary arrangements for a visit by Mr. Gladstone in April next.

The ladies of Grovetown are raising funds with which to erect a memorial church to Paul Hayne. A monument to the memory of the gentle poet could take no more appropriate shape than this, and the Telegraph hopes that the many among its readers who are his admirers will cheerfully aid in making it as nearly worthy of him as may be.

NEWPORT, R.I., Nov. 26.--The citizens of Newport have presented to the Fifth New-York Veteran Association (Duryee's Zouaves) $1,565 for the purpose of assisting that organization in erectting a monument to Gen. G.K. Warren, United States Army, who died and was buried here.
ALBANY, Nov. 26.--Two more affidavits were added by the Republicans to-day to the literature of the Chase-Russell Senatorial contest.

RUTLAND, Vt., Nov.26.--Dr. Middleton Goldsmith, physician, surgeon, and author, died here this afternoon, aged 70 years. He had been President and Professor of several medical colleges. WARSAW, N. Y., Nov. 26.-William Morley, just of age and of magnificent physique, has been lifing salt from the grainers of the Kerr salt Company. PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 26.--The 142-hour go-asyou-please race ended to-night shortly before 10 o'clock, with Littlewood, the Englishman, in first place, nearly 40 miles ahead of his nearest competitor. Following are the scores of the five men at the finish; Littlewood, 569 miles 1 lap; Albert, 530 miles; Panchot, 511 miles 9 laps; Noremac, 501 miles 6 laps; Elson, 500 miles, 1 lap.

GALVESTON, Texas, Nov. 26.--Ex-County Treasurer W.J. Burk, who while in ofice defrauded the county out of $36,000 in bonds and money and about three months ago returned from Australia, whither he had fled, and voluntarily surrendered himself to the San Francisco authorities, was tried here yesterday.

CARLISLE, Penn., Nov. 26.--Frederick Wolff, a Lieutenant-Colonel in the British Indian Army, died suddenly here to-day at his lodgings. He was a bachelor, and a most eccentric character. He served in several European wars, and then went to India. From there, when he was retired, he came to America, and fought in the Union army during the rebellion.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Nov. 26.--The eviction cases of the Stout Coal Company, of Milnesville, against striking miners was decided in favor of the miners this morning. Judge Woodward granted a rule to strike off judgments entered by the company for dispossessing the striking tenants. The men will, under these rulings, hold possession of their houses during the remaining time of the strike and cannot be evicted.

OTTAWA, Nov. 26.--The Hon. G.E. Foster, Minister of Marine and Fisheries, is prostrate with an attack of fever. He was to have left for Washington to-day to present the Canadian side of the flshery question. Mr. Foster suffered from a severe headache yesterday, but attended to his departmental duties late last night.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 26--The Yale Freshmen were defeated by the Harvard Freshmen at football on the Yale field this afternoon. There were six or seven hundred spectators, 100 of them Harvard Freshmen. Yale scored only two points by a touch-down in the first half.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Nov. 26.--The large rhinoceros which was so severly burned at the great fire at Barnum's Winter quarters last Sunday died last night from the effects of its injuries. This makes the rate 38 cents in refrigerator cars, and 35 cents in common cars. They have also published a rate showing a reduction of export rates via Portland, Me., of 3 cents per 100 on provision and 2 cents per 100 on flour.

ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 26.--John Green, the noted safe burglar, who was arrested in Ballston while attempting to rob the Ballston Bank, has been identified by Chief Willard as the same person who was arrested in Canada for safe-breaking and who escaped from Kingston Prison a short time ago.

The bronze statue of Gen. Philip Schuyler has been placed in the niche of the Schuylerville monument by Architect Markham, completing the list of statuary. The vacant niche, with the name inscribed, will speak more eloquently than bronze of the gallantry and treachery of Benedict Arnold.

Howard Van Schaick, the young dry goods clerk who failed to put in an appearance at his own wedding, which was to have taken place on thanksgiving Night at Long Branch, returned to his boarding house in this city on Friday morning apparently none the worse for wear.

Nov. 26.--Petitions are in circulation in all parts of this region, asking Secretary Fairchild to revoke a recent order from the Treasury Department at Washington, to the effect that Japanese peppermint oil may be admitted to the United States free of duty, to be packed here and prepared for export.

DUBLIN, Nov. 20.--The great Unionist meeting, for the purpose of addressing which Lord Hartington and Mr. Goschen visited this city, was held in Leinster Hall this evening. So many persons were desirous of attending that an overflow meeting was held in another hall. Both halis were crowded at an early hour of the evening.

Tin is cornered beyond a shadow of a doubt, and cornered thoroughly all over the world. Prices have been boomed steadily and successfully, and yesterday buyers were offering 34 cents for spot in the Metal Exchange, and sellers were demanding 35 cents a pound.
CHICAGO, Nov. 30.--Judge Tuley this morning rendered an important decision in a suit involving the liability of the Independent Order of Foresters under their insurance policies.

MELBOURNE, Nov. 30.--The American Consul here has applied to the commission having charge of the arrangements for the exhibition to be held in Melbourne for 100,000 square feet of space for American exhibitors.

The first absolutely practical step toward the beginning of work on the long-projected Nicaragua Canal was taken yesterday when an engineering party of 40 young gentlemen sailed from this city for Greytown on the steamship Hondo.

Mr. Platt has encountered some little opposition from an unexpected quarter. He secretly desires the election of Jay Sloat Fassett to the Presidency of the Senate, but some of the Senators upon whom he has always relied are mildly protesting, not to say kicking, against this programme.

DETROIT, Mich., Nov. 30.--The facts relative to the injunction prohibiting the purchase by the Flint and Pere Marquette Railway of the Port Huron and Northwestern Narrow Gauge Road are at last made public. When the Flint and Per Marquette Company was reorganized, about six years ago, the share capital represented $3,000,000 and the loans $7,000,000.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 30.--To-day was the end of Reading's fiscal year, and from now until the date of the annual meeting, Janu. 9, Secretary Foster will be kept busy night and day compiling figures and getting detailed reports in readiness.

LONDON, Nov. 30.--The pendulum seems to-day to be swinging to M. de Freycinet's side. He is working like a beaver, smiling and shaking hands, asking after the families of all the Senators and Deputies like a candidate for Coroner, keeping open house, and making pledges right and left.

Whatever merit Mr. Rider Haggard's thrilling romances may lack they certainly do possess the charm of singularity. "She," in particular, though upon close examination we discover its shallowness and do not accord its author an important place among producers of literature, is a strange thing.

A pine box was carried from an express wagon into the County Clerk's office at 3:55 o'clock yesterday afternoon. It was bigger than a soap box and not as high as a dry goods box. It was taken possession of by Edward Stapleton, law clerk in the office, and he opened it.

The St. Andrew's Society of the State of New-York celebrated its one hundred and thirtyfirst anniversary at Delmonico's last evening. The word celebrated is used advisedly and with full knowledge that it implies contentment, enjoyment, hilarity, and a number of other agreeable conditions of mind and body.

A fashionable home wedding yesterday afternoon was that of Miss Theda Filley, daughter of President Samuel R. Filley, of the Suburban Elevated Railroad, to George Hanford Lally, which took place at the house of the bride's parents, 982 Prospect-avenue, Morrisania.

The Fiftieth Congress opens its first session next Monday. It will extend well into the Summer of next year, and will probably be, like most sessions of Congress held on the eve of a Presidential campaign, fruitful in talk and barren of any substantial results.
Yesterday's stock market was dull and almost featureless, though reports calculated to affect the prices of securities were abundant, good news and bad news being about equally divided.

The annual State Conference of the Unitarian churches of New-York was held in three sessions yesterday at All Souls' Church, Twentieth-street and fourth-avenue. J.H. Rhoades opened the first session at 11 A.M. It was announced that the Harlem Unitarians had called the Rev. Merle St. Croix Wright to their church, or rather to the church they are to have.

A roe shad weighing three and a half pounds was caught in the Hudson River near Dobbs Ferry on Tuesday, and now awaits a purchaser at the fish house of C.A. Weaver Co., 106 Barclay-street, where, with terrapin from Texas and the South, it is about as far off from its native haunts at this season of the year as it could be.

Bagley, Pastor of the Tabernacle Baptist Church on Broadway, Camden, has had some strange experiences in the thousand or so marriages he has performed in that city during his pastorate, but an episode occurred to-night that fairly took the Pastor's breath away.

The Women's National Indian Association met in annual session yesterday morning at the Washington-Avenue Baptist Church, Brooklyn. The association is incorporated under the Pennsylvania laws, and has for its objects the improvement of the general condition of the Indian.

Hummel, marching in, closely followed by George Beane, who plays CyPrime, and by Walter Gale, the "Happy Jack" of that shekel-gathering drama.
A decision of the Court of Appeals must be taken as settling the law upon the particular point in question, because it is the tribunal of final resort and cannot be overruled.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 30.--The Rev. Richard Scannell, Pastor of St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church, this city, was to-day consecrated Bishop of the See of Concordia, Kan., Archbishop Feehan officiating.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30.--The Democratic members of Congress, who are coming in thick and fast, are all submitting to interviews on the tariff question and the proposed reduction of the surplus revenues. They do not have much to say that is new. They dread to think of a failure to check the flow of money into the Treasury.

The first pubic rehearsal of the Oratorio Society attracted a large audience at the Metropolitan Opera House yesterday afternoon. The works performed were Mozart's "Requieum Mass" and the third part of Schumann's "Faust." These are well-known compositions, and it is unnecessary to enter into extended comment upon them.

Herr Johann Most is a pessimist as well as an Anarchist. He said that he was, yesterday, when seen in his narrow cell in the Tombs, and that as he always expected the worst, he was not surprised when the jury brought in a verdict of guilty against him, although he knew his cause to be just.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 30.--Trouble is threatened between the Reading Railroad Company and some of the coal operators in the Lehigh anthracite region, as an outgrowth of the present strike among the miners. Ario Pardee Sons, of Hazleton, on Saturday last consigned 25 carloads of "non-union" coal to dealers in this city by the Reading Railroad.

Nathaniel McKay was elected President, W.H. Davee, Secretary and Treasurer, and C. L. Bushuell, J.B. Pope, and C.V. McKay Directors of the New-Jersey and San Domingo City Bridge Company, which was organized yesterday under the laws of New-Jersey for the purpose of building on iron bridge across the Ozama River under a grant by the municipality of the city of San Domingo.

DUBLIN, Nov. 30.--The Unionist banquet in Leinster Hall this evening was a brilliant affair. The leading merchants and professional men and a number of Catholic Unionists were present. The balconies were crowded with ladies.
GREENFIELD, Mass., Nov. 30.--Lincoln Randall, a 17-year-old boy, is under arrest and locked up here to-night charged with the murder of his father, David M. Randall, a respected farmer, of Montague.

"Lohengrin" was brought forward at the Metropolitan Opera House last evening, and drew together an audience of goodly size. Sometimes "Lohengrin" is well sung and sometimes it is not; but the prophet is not yet born who can tell which time is ripe when he starts for the opera house.
A fire which occurred in a plumbers' supplies factory, at 25 Centre-street, on Tuesday night called to mind one of the most interesting chapters in the early history of New-York banking.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1.--The annual report of the Commissioner of Agriculture was laid before the President to-day. The Commissioner recommends substantially the abolition of the seed division of the department and the transfer of its duties to the State and Territorial experiment stations.

The Pennsylvania Railroad Company yesterday began running from this city what is known as a "Richmond and Danville Dispatch," an all-rail line from this city, via Baltimore and Washington, to all points in the South and Southwest.

The Governor's proclamation published this morning gives the following official figures of the vote on the Constitutional Convention: For a convention, 72,464; against, 105,735; blanks, 8,908. As the convention had to get a majority of all the ballots cast in order to win, it was defeated by 42,179 votes. This is what can be called a very safe majority.

Dennis Smith, of 506 East Thirteenthstreet, owns the double five-story tenement house 345 West Forty-third-street, whose construction is faulty, in that the stairs are tortuous and narrow.

Since Boston Corbett has been placed in the insane asylum his effects at Concordia, Kan., have passed into the hands of an administrator, and among them was the identical Enfield rifle with which Corbett shot the slayer of Lincoln. This old weapon has been purchsed for $5 by a Grand Army of the Republic post at Concordia, and will be kept as a relic.

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 1.--Charnel Hightower, 17 years old, died yesterday morning from the effects of an assault committed on him at 10:30 o'clock Saturday night. Young Hightower returned to the St. George Hotel, of which his father is proprietor, and, entering his brother's room, stated that he had been assaulted and struck on the head with a stone.

Judge Kirkpatrick, of the Newark Court of Common Pleas, handed down a decision yesterday morning which will be of interest to beneficent societies. It was in the case of the Ancient Order of Hibernians against James Quinn.
Mr. William Barnes yesterday brought in from his place in the hills west of town a lot of Bartlett pears of the second crop grown on his trees this year.

DODGEVILLE, Wis., Dec. 1.--News of an explosion on the work of the Freeport, Dodgeville and Northern Road, two miles south of Dodgeville, has just been received. One man and two horses were killed outright and five men burned. The laborers were boring out an unexploded blast.

AUBURN, N.Y., Dec. 1.--Convict Mour, who stowed himself away in the prison a week ago today, was discovered in cell 15, occupied by a convict named McCafferty, at 4 o'clock this afternoon. Keeper Gay was searching the cell, and noticed that the cot felt warm.

BUFFALO, Dec. 1.--A conference was held this week at Jamestown between Assemblymen Frost, Nixon, and Whipple, and several local politicians, at which it was agreed to support Fremont Cole for Speaker of the Assembly. Assemblyman Cheney, of Cattaraugus, was not present, but it is thought that he will act with the other representatives of Chautauqua and Cattaraugus Counties. These gentlemen, it is understood, will not vote for Husted under any circumstances.

CHICAGO, Dec. 1.--"Home and Liberty" was the burden of the speeches at Battery D Armory this morning. The second day's session of the Prohibition National Conference was expected to be a long one, and therefore 9 o'clock was the hour set for the opening.

A meeting of the Beecher Memorial Fund Committee was held at the house of the Rev. Dr. Charles H. Hall, on Montague-street, Brookly, yesterday afternoon, and the Rev. Dr. Joseph Parker, of London, explained his action in connection with the proceeds of his eulogy of Mr. Beecher at the Academy of Music on Oct. 4.

A gentleman who was invited out to dine at a Delaware-avenue residence lately observed that the chandelier over the dining room table was of peculiar construction, so that there was a light over the head of each guest. The globes were of various colors, some amber, some red and some blue.

TROY, N.Y., Dec. 1.--The thermometer fell to 6 above zero this morning. The river is full of anchor ice. At North Lansingburg 2 above a zero was recorded. The Champlain Canal was frozen over at Waterford.

CHATHAM, Mass., Dec. 1.--A heavy northeast gale prevailed all night, and still continues with no signs of abating. There is a very rough sea outside and on the shoals, and the blinding snow squalls allow only occasional observations to be made.

J. Pibloe, a Bohemian mechanic, was turned out of an apartment in the rear of the third floor of 325 East One Hundred and Sixth-street, yesterday, for non-payment of rent. His wife re-entered on the plea that she had forgotten some property, and an hour later paper and rubbish was found on fire in the apartment, and kerosene had been sprinkled on the floor. The woman was arrested for arson.

CHICAGO, Dec. 1.--After two months of consulting, conferring, and meeting at various points all over the country, the Transcontinental Association is an accomplished fact. The final touches were put to it to-day, the interested roads having reached an agreement on all points involved.

The Tenement House Building Company yesterday opened for occupation its row of six six-story tenements on the west side of Cherrystreet, a little south of Montgomery-street, and its agent was kept fairly busy all day exhibiting suites of rooms to applicants and explaining the advantages they offer to tenants.

CHICAGO, Dec. 1.--The sub committees of the Anarchist Defense Committee and the Central Labor Union to-day decided to accept an offer made by the Greenwood Cemetery and bury the five dead Anarchists there.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec, 1.--Chairman Cooper, of the Republican State Committee, will leave the city to-morrow for Washington, where he will remain until after the meeting of the Republican National Committee on Thursday next. His purpose is to catch the members of the committee as they arrive in Washington, and aided by Senators Cameron and Quay, exert his efforts to induce them to fix on Philadelphia as the place of meeting for the Presidential Convention.

In the lobby of the St. James Hotel there stood, yesterday, and will stand for some time a bronze bust of the late John McCullough. It arrived in this city from the Haney-Bonnard foundry, where it was cast, yesterday morning. The bust is of heroic size, about four times the size of a man's head.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Dec. 1.--General rains began falling this morning throughout Western Texas, extending nearly 500 miles west of here and south of the Rio Grande. The rain was badly needed throughout this vast grazing district. The indications point to a copious full.
MONTREAL, Dec. 1.--H.J. Sim, son of the proprietor of the Dominion Hotel, Ottawa, was arrested to-day by a private detective on a charge of swindling Mrs. Barker, a New-York woman, out of $1,000.

One of the best places to visit, if upon pleasure bent or upon holiday purchasing intent, is the fair that will to-day and to-morrow, until late at night, be held at the Hotel Brunswick--Twenty-seventh-street entrance--by the Alumnae of the Normal College for the benefit of their library fund.

To the general public the most interesting matter which will be printed on the December pilot chart of the North Atlantic Ocean, to be issued the latter part of this week, is a description of globular lightning--that strangest of all electric phenomena--seen by Capt. Moore, of the British steamship Siberian.
WINNIPEG, Manitoba., Dec. 1.--His Honor, the Lieutenant-Governor, has been requested by Cabinet Ministers to summon the Manitoba Legislature for dispatch of business between Jan. 10 and 16.

PARIS, Dec. 1.--President Grevy this forenoon informed the Ministerial Council that, in view of the change in the situation, he did not propose to make a communication to Parliament to-day. He informed M. Rouvier that he believed that public opinion was now in his favor and that he could from a new Cabinet.

James M.C. Martin, a member of the Chamber of Commerce, died suddenly yesterday at his brush factory, 107 Fulton-street, from failure of the action of the heart. He came to the city from his home at Brick Church, N.J. Early in the morning ...

In the Oregon Transcontinental suit against the St. Paul and Northern Pacific Railway Company in the United States Circuit Court begun during the Summer the answer of the defendants has just been filed.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1.--Lieut.-Col. Henry C. Hodges, Deputy Quartermaster-General, has been ordered to remain in New-York City until Jan. 15 for the purpose of settling his accounts, and then go to Louisville, Ky. The resignation of Cadet Harry L. Conn, Fourth Class, Military Academy, has been accepted by the Secretary of War.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., Dec. 1.--The stocks of oil and whalebone in first hands in this country today, as compared with those of a year ago, are as follows: Dec, 1, 1886--Sperm oil, 21,105 barrels; whale oil, 11,500 barrels: bone, 33,600 pounds. Dec. 1, 1887--Sperm oil, 17,545 barrels; whale oil, 33,750 barrels; bone, 512,300 pounds.
The arrival of the ship James A. Boreland at San Diego, Cal., ends the first voyage of a new line between this port and Southern California.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 1.--The New-Jersey Supreme Court has decided as unconstitutional the act under which, in several counties of the State, the charge and care of county prisoners has been transferred from the Sheriffs to the Jail Wardens.

DUBLIN, Dec. 1.--At a meeting of the corporation to-day Lord Mayor Sullivan stated that his name had been omitted in the commission which is to open the Assizes to-morrow. He believed the omission to be illegal, and he intended to accompany the Judges to court.

CHICAGO, Dec. 1.--George R. Davis, the Blaine boss of Cook County, and Warren F. Leland started for Washington to-day to use their influence with the members of the Republican National Committee to induce them to designate Chicago as the place for the National Convention of the party next year.

Little Josef Hofmann, the wonderful boy, has captured the town. His second concert, which took place at the Metropolitan Opera House yesterday aftetnoon, was attended by an audience that filled every seat and box in the large auditorium, while many persons were obliged to stand throughout the performance.

LONDON, Dec. 1.--The Jura fox has doubled on his pursuers. Having apparently consented to resignation, and even fixed a day for it, President Grevy now turns around and says things have changed, and that he has concluded not to resign after all.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Dec. 1.--A 12-year old boy named John Engle created a reign of terror in the town of Nanticoke last evening. He bought several revolvers, two bowie knives, and other weapons. Some person also gave him some liquor.
The fifteenth annual reception of the Home for Old Men and Aged Couples was held at the home, 487 Hudson-street, yesterday afternoon. The old people received their friends in the parlors.

The Grand Opera House was crowded yesterday afternoon from 1 o'clock until 5, and the Actors' Fund is richer by a large sum of money. The entertainment offered on the stage did not differ much in character from those usually provided for similar purposes. The quality was generally good.
The Dolphin and the Atlanta arrived at the Brooklyn Navy Yard yesterday from Newport.

Washington E. Connor was the officer of the day at the Masonic Fair yesterday, and as for some days he had been giving his brother bankers quiet tips about the splendid chances for investment to be had at the fair, they were present in strong force, and helped greatly to swell the day's receipts.

The big French syndicate which has been making things lively in the tin and copper markets of the world by, so far, successful corners has now turned its attention to lead. On the New-York Metal Exchange yesterday lead advanced about 3/8 of a cent a pound, December closing at 5.05 cents. The transactions for the day amounted to about 300,000 pounds, which was taken, it is said, by the syndicate's representative.

Mrs. Ida May Grover has brought an action in the Supreme Court for absolute divorce against her husband, Leonard Grover, the aged actor. She charged him with infidelity with various persons unknown to her.

LONDON, Dec. 1.--The Lancet says: "Dr. Mackenzie receives highly satisfactory advices concerning the condition of the German Crown Prince. In view of the fact that there is no actual microscopical proof of the existence of cancer the diminution of the swelling is not without a certain degree of clinical importance."

The St. Nicholas Society, at its meeting at Delmonico's last evening, unanimously voted to increase its possible membership from 500 to 600. Between 50 and 60 candidates are waiting to be admitted, some of whom have been waiting for several years.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Dec. 1.--A double tragedy is reported to-day from Choctaw Nation. Ten days ago the wife of a planter named Robert Oliver, living in Scott County this State, eloped with a man named James Yancey, who was employed by her husband. The two fled to the Indian Territory. Oliver pursued and overtook them soon after they crossed the border. A fight took place, in which both men were mortally wounded.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 1.--The election for Mayor here to-day resulted as follows: Robbins, (Rep.) 5,189; McNally, (Dem.) 2,802; Blodgett (Proh.) 253; scattering, 16.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Dec. 1.--The unveiling of the Garfield statue which was made by Niehaus and paid for by a popular subscription, was set for this afternoon. The statue is bronze, of heroic size, and stands on a granite pedestal at the intersection of Race and Eighth streets.

IT is the custom at the Tombs before a prisoner who has been convicted of a crime for which the death penalty is inflicted is taken to court for sentence to search him closely. Such prisoners have been known to assault the sentencing Judges with concealed weapons; hence the precaution.

ITHACA, N.Y., Dec. 2.--At Cornell University to-day a large and magnificent portrait of George Bancroft, the historian, was unveiled. The portrait was presented to the university a few days ago by some unknown friend.

PARIS, Dec. 2.--President Grevy's resignation was sent to the President of the Senate and Chamber of Deputies to-day. At 1:25 P.M. crowds were in front of the Chamber of Deputies. The police cleared the approaches to the building and stopped traffic in the vicinity. Soon after the opening of the Chamber the message of resignation was read.

PARIS, Dec. 2.--The town is reasonably quiet. The streets are full of people, but there are no signs of a concerted demonstration. Perhaps it is too lightly assumed, however, that no danger need be feared.

There is great joy among the colored folk in Harlem in consequence.
Charles S. Francis, one of tha most noteworthy book publishers of his time--and his time covered a great many years--died at Tarrytown on Thursday, and will be buried there this afternoon.

LONDON, Dec. 2.--Mr. Bradlaugh has written a letter in which he maintains that Lord Salisbury sent a check to promote a fair trade meeting in Trafalgar-square in 1886. Mr. Bradlaugh says he is ready to produce evidence if the Government assents to an inquiry by a committee of the House of Commons.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2.--Mr. Thomas B. Reed, of Maine, has views about the probability of a reduction of the tariff by the Fiftieth Congress, and he has to-day expressed them at length in the form of an argument for the protectionist.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2.--Second Lieut. Blantou C. Welsh, Fifteenth Infantry, has been granted an extended leave of absence of seven days. Leave of absence for two months has been granted to Second Lieut. William S. Wassell, Ninth Infantry.

Delmonico's big dining room was occupied on Wednesday night by people who ate haggis and drank champagne. On Thursday night it was taken possession of by people who did not eat haggis but had no objection to champagne. Last night it was leased by people who neither ate haggis nor drank champagne.

Senator Hiscock having gone to Washington, the work of doling out the patronage of the Legislature devolves upon Boss Platt. The politicians will continue to flock to him for some weeks to come.

They said that the present dullness in the livery business did not warrant the advance demanded by the men, and that they would certainly not accede to the men's demands without a struggle.

Susie Eckstein, aged 19 years, of Long Island City, was outrageously assaulted by a gang of roughs in Woodside late Sunday night. The girl lost her way home and was found by the gang, who dragged her to a barn and kept her there until this afternoon, when they released her. The police are looking for the miscreants.

There has been for the last five years a continuous effort on the part of the State of Virginia, to avoid the fulfillment of her contract with the bondholders and taxpayers of the State by which she agreed in the Refunding act of 1871 to receive the coupons of the bonds issued thereunder in payment of all taxes and public dues.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Dec. 5.--This morning while standing at Stellarton Station, on the Intercolonial Railroad, Locomotive No. 170 exploded with terrific force. The explosion was so severe that houses in the vicinity rocked like cradles and houses half a mile distant shook perceptibly.

CHICAGO, Dec. 5.--The visible supply of grain as estimated by the Secretary of the Board of Trade shows a stock of wheat amounting to 40,000,000 bushels, an increase of 899,000 bushels; corn, 5,000,000 bushels, decrease of 870,000 bushels; cats, 6,000,000 bushels, decrease of 50,000 bushels; rye, 280,000 bushels, decrease of 41,000 bushels; barley, 3,600,000 bushels, decrease of 81,000 bushels.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 5.--The Hodgen Commission Company, whose main office is in Louisville, with branches at Cincinnati, Evansville, Indianapolis, Chicago, Pittsburg, Cleveland, and Baltimore, is reported failed today on account of the steady rise in markets. The firm is a brokerage or "bucket-shop" concern. The total liabilities are estimated at from $90,000 to $150,000, with assets amounting to $40,000. The liabilities of the Cincinnati branch are estimated at $28,000.

The sun grazes the tropic of Capricorn on the 21st of December and the astronomical Winter commences. The event is known as the Winter solstice. It is the season when ice and snow reign over the northern temporate zone, and the sun looks with slanting beams upon a belt of earth when cold and desolation hold sway.

At the meeting of the Fisheries Commissioners yesterday it was resolved that the oyster beds under Smithtown Bay are not a natural growth, and are therefore the subject of grant by the commission under the laws of the State of New-York affecting the sale of oyster lands.

The committees of the Hospital Saturday and Sunday Association have entered upon their annual canvass of the trades. To trades not yet organized into auxiliaries subscription lists have been mailed, and it is hoped that in all mercantile and manufacturing establishments where such lists are received the employers and employes will make common cause in behalf of a charity from which 28 hospitals now derive support.

The family of Isaac Diamond, a barber, who lives over his shop at 428 Fifth-avenue, Brooklyn, had a narrow escape from death by burning shortly after 1 o'clock yesterday morning. The building, is of brick and three stories high. His family, consisting of a wife and five children, live on the top floor. About 1 o'clock a fire broke out in the cellar, and Diamond was one of the first to reach the street.

GALVESTON, Texas, Dec. 5.--The north-bound Missouri Pacific passenger train from San Antonio was wrecked near Kyle last night. Charles Wood, yard engineer at Austin, who was riding on the locomotive with the regular engineer, was instantly killed. Engineer P. Smith and Fireman Brooks were seriously injured.

CHICAGO, Dec. 5.--Traffic Manager G.B. Reeve, of the Chicago and Grand Trunk, has returned from the Montreal conference. His return has not been signalized by any further reduction in dressed beef rates, nor is it probable that there will be any more for some time to come.

DUBLIN, Dec. 5.--The National electors of West Waterford held a demonstration to-day and presented 200 guineas to Mr. Pyne, their representative in Parliament. Mr. Pyne, in a speech thanking the electors, gave notice to the police that he would leave his castle on Tuesday and would remain out three days. Mr. Gilhooly, member of Parliamant for Cork, has not been arrested, as was reported a few days ago. He visited Mr. Pyne to day.

PRINCETON, N.J. Dec. 5.--The Princeton College football team to-day elected H.W. Cowan, Class of '88, Captain for next season. He is considered the finest rusher in America, and, although he graduates from the college next June, will return to take a post graduate course and enter the seminary.

The matinee performance of Josef Hofmann, the boy pianist, to be given in the Metropolitan Opera House this afternoon, will begin at 4 o'clock, the hour being used so as to enable school children to attend the performance without interfering with their studies.

The Brooklyn Common Council yesterday increased the salary of "Jim" Dunne, the Keeper of the City Hall, from $1,900 to $2,500 a year. Dunne is an ex-prize fighter. He has been in the courts several times for assaults upon his political associates.

Gov. Hill is about to take lessons in horseback riding. His private secretary, Col. Rice, is an expert horseman, and the Governor has finally yielded to his persuasions to accompany him mornings in a canter over the country.

The road will be some 300 miles in length. Starting from opposite this city it crosses the St. Johns River 70 miles...

A German excursionist has just completed his tour round the world. He went from Berlin and back via Brindisi, Alexandria, Aden, SingaPore, Hong-Kong, Yokohama, San Francisco, New-York, and Bremerhaven. The voyage took him 185 days, and his expenses amounted to 180, or a little under 1 a day. He says the tour can be done for less, but not comfortably.

Two meetings were held at the office of Commissioner Fink yesterday. One was that of the General Baggage Agents of the trunk lines, who discussed details of the plan to check baggage to San Francisco and left final action to the General Passenger Agents. The other was that of the rate clerks. who went to work on a new table of fares for next year, but made no important changes in the existing tariffs.

The Sheriff has taken charge of the store of Corn, Clark Co., wholesale dealers in optical goods at 44 Maiden-lane. They confessed judgments in favor of Joseph Clark, $3,133, and H. Levy Brother, $1,917. Judgment for $1,219 was also entered against N.E. Clark individually. The business was started in February, 1886, as Corn Clark, and the present firm succeeded them April 28, 1887, claiming $12,000 cash capital, contributed by Mr. Clark.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 5.--While the funeral services of Thomas Casey were progressing to-day the floor gave way, and the body of mourners, with the coffin, were precipitated into the room below. Some of them were badly bruised, but not seriously injured.

"Snapper" Garrison's very promising colt by Spendthrift, out of Phyllis, she by imp. Phaeton, died at Sheepshead Bay yesterday of pneumonia. The colt cost Garrison $2,400 at the Spendthrift sale last October, and was well engaged for 2-year-old stakes next year, including the rich Futurity Stakes.

BENNINGTON, Vt., Dec. ,5.--The Bacon homestead and barns in Sunderland were destroyed by fire this morning. The loss is $4,000; partially insured. E.G. Bacon, age 35 years, perished in the flames. Mr. Bacon was a prominent Democrat and highly respected.

Every one recognizes without difficulty that much of the work of the next Presidential contest for both parties will be done in the session of Congress that opened yesterday.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Dec. 5.--A locomotive on the Intercolonial Railroad exploded to-day at Stellarton Station, killing three men instantly and injuring several others. The engine was completely demolished and the station building was badly wrecked.

On Thursday evening next the Nineteenth Century Club will talk about "Our Triumphant Democracy." It is understood that Mr. Andrew Carnegie will discuss the question from an optimistic standpoint, while Mr. Lawrence Grunland will give his views as a Socialist. It was rumored that when Mr. Grunland received his formal invitation from the club to attend...
Extensive and very costly decorative works are about to be commenced in the chateau of Chantilly by order of the Due d'Aumale, and the galleries are to be altered and improved.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 5.--Samuel M. Hotchkiss, Commissioner of Labor Statistics for Connecticut, has compiled an abstract of the reports of 66 families for the month of October, 1887, furnished to the Bureau of Labor Statistics by the persons themselves, in compliance with his request for information enabling him to compare wages received with the cost of living.

The trial of the Suit of Georgia Fargo, the daughter of William G. Fargo, of the WellsFargo Express Company, against James H. and Charles Fargo and Franklyn D. Locke, the Executors and Trustees under her father's will, was begun before judge Truax, in the Superior Court, yesterday, and after a small amount of testimony had been taken was but over for a week.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Dec. 5.--A sensational episode occurred at St. Paul's Episcopal Church, in this city, late last night, that developed to-day into a bitter open controversy between the Pastor, Dr. G.W. Dumbell, and two young men, J.M. Chancey and J.N. Caldwell. At the Sunday night service Dr. Dumbell...

CHICAGO, Dec. 5.--Negotiations are underway between the Union Pacific and the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul, looking to the formation of a traffic contract between the Kansas Pacific line of the former and the Kansas City extension of the latter. The object, of course, is for the interchange of through...

Capt. Alexis C. Smith, of Company H, was unanimously chosen by the staff of commissioned officers of the Twenty-third Regiment as Lieutenant-Colonel last evening, to succeed Alexander S. Bacon, who resigned two months ago, Lieut.-Col. Smith has a good record in the National Guard.

The arrangements for the funeral of Algernon S. Sullivan have not yet been completed. It has been decided, however, that the funeral services will be held in the First Presbyterian Church, Eleventh-street and Fifthavenue, Thursday morning at 10 o'clock. The interment will be in Greenwood.

WATERLOO, N.Y., Dec. 5.--The interest among the people in Central and Western NewYork in the extensive operations that are going on in all parts of this region with a view to finding natural gas and petroleum is daily increasing.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5.--Secretary Bayard has given Congress his reasons, in submitting estimates for the appropriations for the diplomatic and consular service, for all the increased items to be embodied in the regular appropriation bill. He clears up the subject in a long letter...

COLCHESTER, Nov. 3.--To most Englishmen (and very probably to most foreigners likewise) Colchester is simply a place which is famous for its oysters. Few save the most incorrigible antiquaries would ever think of connecting it with that jovial potentate of our nursey ballads, "Old King Cole."

Dockstader is in trouble. He advertised yesterday for a musical prodigy to impersonate Josef Hofmann. He advertised as calmly for a musical prodigy as if musical prodigies were as common as lost dogs and were running around the streets with tags on them like incarnated Mozarts, Beethovens, and Bartholdys.

CHICAGO, Dec. 5.--A beer pool to be known as the Chicago and Milwaukee Brewers' Association was organized here to-day. The membership is said to include every beer manufacturing firm in the two cities. Michael Keeley, of Chicago, was elected President.

Some years ago George W. Child joined a local lodge of the A.O.U.W. and arranged to have the certificate for the $2,000 benefit paid to his betrothed, a young lady in Canada. A few years ago she learned that Child had a wife living in England, but that he was seeking divorce from her in the Wayne Circuit Court.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Dec. 5.--Charles Walker, of this city, has absconded with about $6,000 of his employers' money. He was bookkeeper for the Cincinnati Spring Company. The books of the firm are missing and the exact amount of the defalcation is not known. A warrant was sworn out for Walker today on the charge of embezzlement.

The venerable poet, Jules Lacroix, died last week at the age of 78. He was a brother of Paul Lacroix, Bibliophile Jacob, and brotherin-law of Balzac, his wife being a Countess Rzewuska and sister of Mme. Hanska, who became Mme. de Balzac.
The exciting melodrama called "The pavements of Paris" began a week at the Windsor Theatre last evening.

A servant girl in Forty-third-street, according to report, started in in the dark of Thursday morning to build a fire with kerosene. Her intention was laudable her ambition was small, but her achievement was great.

Eugene Carter, victor of the cushion-carrom tournament in Chicago, has been before the public as a billiard player about 17 years. He won nine of the ten games he had to play in the Chicago tournament, which was a handicap.

The spectacle called "The Arabian Nights," that was lately on exhibition at the little Standard Theatre, was put upon the ample stage of the Academy of Music last evening where there is plenty of room for the ballet and the scenic transformations, and the frolicsome spirit of Miss Lena Merville is not confined...

The prices which have been obtained recently for autograph letters at the salesrooms in the Hotel Drouot suggest peculiar reflections as to the relative value of the celebrities who penned them and the estimation in which they were held by the purchasers. Eight letters of Mme. de Stael have just been bought for 20; 8 was given for a single letter of Camille...

A new and potent attraction has been added to those which have heretofore combined to make the Eden Musee a desirable place to visit. The addition is Erdelyi Naczi and his Hungarian orchestra, whose first performances were given last evening. The players--14 in number-include a half dozen first violins,

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 5.--The annual meeting of the Stockholders of the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad Company will be held in this city Dec. 21. The annual report of the Directors will be made through President Charles P. Clark.
Col. William A. Jones, Deputy Collector at the Public Stores, was yesterday removed from office by the Secretary of the Treasury, acting upon the recommendation of Collector Magone.

Two more "green-goods" swindlers were hauled in by the police yesterday, and all the paraphernalia for their game was likewise captured. The latest squirmers in the police net are Charles A. Forth, alias Frost, alias Ford,

Bustling times were the rule on the Produce Exchange yesterday and speculation was extremely lively, prices jumping way up and then coming down somewhat in a way that kept the brokers hustling. In corn there was heavy buying by the shorts, both West and here,

For the first time in many years there was a genuine fight last night among the members of the Kings County Democratic General Committee. It was caused by the action of Boss John Y. McKane, of Gravesend, and Boss C.J. Ferguson, of New-Utrecht, in kicking against the rule of Boss McLaughlin.

The suit of the Rev. J.J. White against the First Methodist Church, on Grand-street, Williamsburg, to have set aside a conveyance of its property to the South Fourth-Street Church in order to satisfy a claim of his for back salary, was decided in favor of the defendants yesterday by Judge VanWyck in the Brooklyn City Court.

John J. Delaney, a boy of 19 years, is locked up in the Adams-street station house. Brooklyn, as a self-confessed murderer. He visited the station house on Saturday night while drunk and asked Capt. Campbell the penalty for murder. Upon learning it he said he had...

BOSTON, Mass., Dec. 5.--Gustavus Andrews, the old deputy Sheriff who officiated at the execution of Prof. Webster for the murder of Dr. Parkman, and who years ago was the jailer of Suffolk County Jail, died in Lynn on Sunday in the seventyseventh year of his age. He was a member of the old Boston police of half a century ago and afterward deputy Sheriff.
PARIS, Dec. 5.--President Carnot, at his reception to the retiring Rouvier Cabinet last evening, thanked them for the patriotic devotion they had shown during the recent crisis.

NEWTON, N.J., Dec. 5.--Henry Simonson and Dolsen Ayers, of Beemerville. Sussex Country, returned from a long hunting trip in Pike Country, Penn., on Saturday last. Among other large game they killed two large black bears, one of which came near finishing Mr. Simonson.

BRUNSWICK, Me., Dec. 5.--Gov. Bodwell and wife arrived at Brunswick at noon to-day on their way to Rockland. The Governor was taken suddenly ill in the station here and returned home on the next train.

ALBANY, Dec. 5.--The General Term this afternoon affirmed the order of Judge Ingalls, which directs the Board of County Canvassers to canvass the returns for Senator in this, the Seventeenth, district filed in the County Clerk's office.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 5.--A decided sensation was created to-day when Prosecuting Attorney Huling addressed the Criminal Court, requesting a special Grand Jury for the trial of certain persons for active work in connection with the celebrated tally-sheet frauds, committed in this city in 1885. It is understood that certain persons implicated in the changing of the sheets have turned State's evidence,

NEWBURYPORT, Mass., Dec. 5.--The resignation of R.K. Manaton, Pastor of the Washington-Street Methodist Church, was announced yesterday. Certain charges had been made against him relative to a young lady of the congregation which they both deny. Mr. Manaton, however, thought it advisable to resign.

SCRANTON, Penn., Dec. 5.--The body of a murdered stranger was found in the woods on the side of the Moosic Mountains, a short distance from Olyphant, yesterday afternon, by three young men who were out for a walk. The discovery was first made by a dog that accompanied the men. The murdered man lay face downward in the snow, and from the manner in...

A few days ago the Connecticut Commissioner of Insurance procured an injuction forbidding the Continental Life Insurance Company of Hartford to pay out any money or transfer any of its property, and applied to the courts for the appointment of a Receiver.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Dec. 5.--The first National Convention of Journeymen Barbers met in this city today. Mr. H.G. Hoch, of Muskegon, Mich., was elected temporary Chairman. There were present Messrs. William Wietan, of Chicago; Patrick J. Hayburne, of NewYork; Edward Finkelstone, of New-York;

The managers of the New-York Bible and Fruit Mission held their annual meeting yesterday at the Coffee House, 416 East Twenty-sixthstreet. Mrs. M.A. Elder presided, and there were present Mrs. Rebecca Collins, Miss A.B. Day, Miss H.S. Darling, Mrs. William F. Mott,

The entertainment for the benefit of the Industrial School for poor Girls, to be given at the Metropolitan Opera House on the evening of Dec. 27, promises to be a great success. DAYTON, Ohio, Dec. 5.--A big sensation was produced here in railroad circles to-day by the filing in Common Pleas Coast of petitions against the Dayton, Fort Wayne and Chicago Railroad asking that the road be placed in the hands of a Receiver.

LONDON, Dec. 5.--The hearing in the case of Thomas Callan, of Lowell, Mass., and Michael Harkins, of Philadelphia, the alleged dynamiters, was resumed to-day. The public was excluded from the court room. Evidence was furnished showing that Callan had received letters signed James Scott, Lowell, Mass., containing bills.

CHATHAM, Ontario, Dec. 5.--The possenger steamer C.H. Merritt, which plied between this port and Detroit, was burned this morning. She was valued at about $18,000, and was insured as follows: British American Insurance Company, $2,500; Queens, $2,500, and Commercial Union, $3,000. She was owned by G.B. Merritt, Samuel Burfoot, and Capt. Cornette.

CHICAGO, Dec. 5.--It was stated is a dispatch to THE NEW-YORK TIMES some days ago that it was the intention to bring an immense pressure to bear on Receiver McNulta, of the Wabash, to induce him to advance the rates to Illinois points on his line. The statement is borne out by the facts and the happenings...

Is not the money-grubbing purpose shown by the President's son-in-law wonderful? He was very rich when he went to the Elysee, and nobody thought him grasping. Opportunity, his case, has created the vice. I rather like Rochefort's notion of employing him at the Executive mansion as an auctioneer for the public sale of tobacco and match monopolies and offices in the civil service.

The excellent memory of Detectives Cottrell, of the Twenty-seventh Precinct, brought two thieves to grief yesterday morning and has made the capture of two more probable. NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 5.--"Fitznoodle," a new comedy, was this evening's attraction at Wall's Opera House, and it was well received by a large audience. Its authors are J.G. Wilson, author of Nordeck," and Benjamin B. Valentine, formerly an editor of Puck. The scene is laid in a Murray Hill mansion, where Mr. Matchbang, a retired grocer, receives Lord Fitznoodle,

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5.--The Fiftieth Congress has met and organized. In both the Senate and the House the ceremonies were witnessed by the usual throngs of people, while up and down in the halls between the two chambers streamed hundreds of sightseers who were unable to obtain admission either to the upper of lower branch.

In four days the entries will close for the poultry, pigeon, and toy dog show to be held at Madison-Square Garden next week. Already about 1,000 entries are reported. The officers of the Poultry Exchange, under whose direction the show is to be held, say they expect quite as many more during the week, and are confident that the show will be superior to any of its predecessors under the Fanciers' Association.

LANCASTER, Penn., Dec. 5.--This morning the whole town was thrown into a state of excitement over the report that a murder had been committed in the eastern end. Investigation showed that the story was correct, and that an old man had come to his death, as is supposed, at the hands of his son.
Representatives from 17 of the ward associations of the Brooklyn Young Republican Club met at the headquarters of the club, on Montague-street, last night, and elected the following officers:
The stock market was buoyant yesterday, and many of the prominent stocks scored smart advances, St. Paul and Union Pacific were the leaders in the rise.
Gen. W.P. Carlin, United States Army, is at the Sturtevant House. Commander F.M. Green, United States Navy, is at the Hoffman House.

A grand fancy bazzar for the benefit of St. Luke's Home for Indigent Christian Females is to be held this week at the Hotel Brunswick, Fifth-avenue and Twenty-seventhstreet, beginning Thursday. Dec. 8, and continuing to and including Saturday, Dec. 10. The doors will be open from 12 M. to 10 P.M.,

In looking over some old papers at the Custom House yesterday an interesting letter was discovered. It was written Oct. 8, 1884. was signed by Mercer Langston, then Consul at Port au Prince, and was directed to James T. Caulk, Secretary of the Republican State Committee of Maryland. It is supposed to have got mixed up with a duplicate invoice from Hayti,
The loan exhibition of historical portraits is now open at the Academy of Fine Arts, Philadelphia.

Col. Pryor L. Mynatt, a distinguished member of the Atlanta bar, passed through Cartersville last Sunday on his way home from a visit to his aged mother, who lives at Pine Log, in this county. While in the city the Colonel told a strange, and startling story to a few friends. Col. Mynatt is an excellent gentleman, whose integrity is above suspicion;

SCRANTON, Penn., Dec. 5.--Veteran hunters hereabout report deer unusually plentiful this season in the wilds of Clearfield County, where nature still holds her own against the encroachments of civilization with a degree of tenacity quite unexpected in any portion of the Keystone State.

The schooner Haze, of Trenton, with some 400 tons of soft coal, from Philadelphia for New-York, sauk near the month of the Delaware and Raritan Canal Sunday night. The tug Relief is now transferring the coal to lighters.
In February, 1884, Manuel Viadero intrusted $100 worth of furniture with James Mirton, Jr., an auctioneer, to sell for him. Morton did sell it, but Viadero got none of the proceeds.

Probate has been granted of the will, dated Sept. 30 last, of the late George Fordham, the jockey, who died at Slough on the 12th nit. UTICA, Dec. 5.--The Utica Board of Trade held its last cheese market day for the season of 1887 to-day. The attendance was large and the members were in good humor, as became men who could look back upon the most prosperous season in their experience and count larger profits than had ever before blessed the cheese trade of Central New-York.

SALT LAKE, Dec. 5.--Eliza R. Snow, the Mormon poetess, died here today. She is alleged to have been the plural wife of Joe Smith at Nauvoo, which she afterward confessed and added Smith to her name. She is one the central figures of the Mormon galaxy, and the church organ to-night has over a two-column editorial on her death. She was in her eighty-fourth year.

On the Metal Exchange yesterday business was comparatively quiet. The market was in sympathy with English fluctuations. During the forenoon cable reports indicated a drop of 10 in tin, and in the afternoon there was a recovery of 5.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 5.--To-day, after three years of shrewd financial warfare, the direct control of the St. Louis Gas Company passed into the hands of the Trust and the Water Gas Syndicate. The Trust is now safely intrenched on Olive-street, and the sensational manipulation by which its success was obtained is a matter of recent local history.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 5.--The Harper trial was resumed to-day, with Mr. Schofield, of the First National Bank of New-York, on the stand to make some additions to his testimony. Among other things he stated that his bank had a claim of $250,000 against Receiver Armstrong, of the Fidelity Bank. Bookkeeper Walters was then cross-examined at considerable length.

Charles Eissner, one of the head waiters at the Hoffman House, was arrested yesterday at his residence, 396 Sixth-avenue, charged with cruelly beating his son Henry, a bright, intelligent little fellow, 11 years old. The child's mother is dead, and a stepmother roles in her stead. The lad said to Justice Gorwan yesterday that whenever his stepmother complained...

A fair given by the Alexander Hamilton Post, No. 182, G.A.R., which will close to-morrow evening, was opened last evening in the West End Hall, One Hundred and Twenty-fifth street, between Seventh and Eighth avenues. The fair was gotten up by the wives of the members to provide a larger relief fund.

ALBANY, Dec. 5.--Gen. James Winsome Husted flow through this city last night, his tail feathers bearing due east, and his beak pointed toward Western New-York. The wind was from the northeast and was accompanied with a drenching rain.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 5.--General Master Workman Powderly was not at the headquarters of the Knights of Labor to-day. A reporter who searched for him to ask his views on the circular issued by the "Provisional Committee" of the malcontents of the order, laid the matter be...

Justice Charles F. Brown opened a special term of the Court of Oyer and Terminer at Belvidere, Long Island, yesterday, for the purpose of trying Franklin A. Hawkins, indicted for murder in the first degree for the killing of his mother at Islip on Oct. 1, and George Goebelein, indicted for the murder of Mrs. Catherine Schauffert at Breslau on Oct. 8.

When I was in Louisville, Ky., a while ago I visited the "Institution for the Blind." While walking across the grounds I saw some boys under the trees playing with a ball and bat. I asked: "What boys are those?" "They are blind boys;" said the Superintendent.

The old fire laddies who, in the days gone by did a good deal of fighting, forgot their enmities last night, and under the glare of lights and the enticing strains of a brass band, danced their way into the affections of the widows and orphans who are cared for by the Brooklyn Veteran Volunteer Firemen's Association. The ball was given at the Academy of Music,
