INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 5.--The Hon W.D. Foulke, author of "Slav or Saxon, will write a biography of Senator Morton, and has commenced the collection of materials for the work.

There is a deficit of about 50,000 in the finances of the exhibitions which have been held at Liverpool during the last two years. The amount of the guarantee fund is 90,000. The speculation of reopening the exhibition this year has proved very disatrous.
The great Masonic Fair has done more to make success an old story than anything that has happened since Mayor Hewitt made his first experiment in letter writing.
I cannot think that Cousin Jonathan really likes his Washington now that he has got it, for it is a most uncomfortable city, built to gratify a disordered palate.
The fifth annual meeting of the New-York State Constitutional Amendment Association was held in the Franklin-Street Methodist Episcopal Church yesterday.

NORFOLK, Va., Dec. 6.--The British steamship Kimberley, ashore 30 miles south of Cape Henry, is to night, leaking badly. It is probable that she will soon break up. The vessel was abandoned by the crew this afternoon. She is now so near the beach that it is thought that when the strong easterly winds and high tides subside it will be possible to walk on board of her.

The Democratic politicians who lofter about the Brooklyn City Hall laughed heartily yesterday over the charges of treachery preferred against John Y. McKane and Cornelius J. Ferguson, at the meeting of the General Committee on Monday night.

It was a distinguished company of theologians who occupied the pulpit platform of Adams Chapel in the Union Theological Seminary last night. They had come together to speak a word about their former colleague, the Rev. Dr. R.D. Hitchcock, ...
The Astor Pavilion, the first of the series of buildings which are to form the New-York Cancer Hospital, was opened yesterday afternoon.
In the Court of General Sessions yesterday William Clark, a sailor, was convicted of illegal voting and was sentenced by Recorder Smyth to one year and ten months in State prison.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 6.--The 2-year-old bay colt by Chichester, dam Chinchilla, by Harold, has been purchased by F. Spillman, of Lawrenceburg, Ky., from W.B. Gratz, of Spring Station, for $1,000. The 5-year-old b. s. Smithwood, by Wildwood, 2:30, dam by Mambrino Patchen, has been purchased by E.F. Murphy, of New-York City, from R. S. Strader, of this county, for $1,000.

PITTSBURG, Dec. 6.--John Armytage, arrested on a charge of forging the name of J.W. Mackay of California, and for attempting fraud, was identified to-day as Orth Stein, a swindler of national reputation. Stein is wanted by the authorities of Cincinnati, St. Louis, and a number of other Western cities. His hearing was postponed in order to give the detectives an opportunity to look up new evidence.
There has seldom been so large an audience at a matinee in the Metropolitan Opera House as assembled yesterday afternoon to hear little Josef Hofmann play the piano.
SAVANNAH, Ga., Dec.6.--At Thomasville to-day the collapse of a water tower killed four men outright and caused serious injury to four others--one of whom cannot live.

PITTSBURG, Dec. 6.--By an explosion of a barrel of oil at Byer's rolling mill this morning Bernard Burns, an employe, was fatally injured. His clothing was entirely burned from his body, and his flesh was roasted to a crisp.
The Irish Brigade Veteran Association met yesterday at the Coroner's office to complete the details for the monument at Gettysburg to its members who felt there.
Mr. CLEVELAND has done an act of statesmanship in the best sense. Recognizing a great duty, he has performed it with courage, with firmness, and at the right time.
The almost phenomenal excellence of this vintage of "Mumm's Extra Dry Champagne" now coming into market is received by connoisseurs as a sensation. English and American clubs are delighted.
"The Merchant of Venice" was put forward by Mr. Irving at the Star Theatre last evening before a numerous and enthusiastic assemblage.
In club circles there is a deep speculation as to the probable fate of E. Berry Wall. The story is current that he is being pursued by a man with blood in his eye and a personal claim in his pocket.
BOSTON, Dec. 6.--J.W. Nightingale, special officer of the United States, has been in the city recently pursuing a quiet investigation.

SAN REMO, Dec. 6.--The Crown Prince drove to Ospedaletto this morning. From there he rode to Colla. The Prince's voice is regaining its strength, though it is still hoarse. This afternoon he walked through San Remo.

JACKSON, Miss., Dec. 6.--At Lake, in Scott County, about 40 miles west of here, last night a band of regulators went to a house occupied by two colored brothers named Williams, it is supposed for the purpose of punishing them for misdemeanors.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 6.--Drafts--Sight, 30 cents; telegraphic, 40 cents.
Mrs. Annie Hawkins, a middle-aged woman, who keeps a boarding house at 70 Willoughbystreet, Brooklyn, was arrested last niglit on a warrant charging her with arson.
INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 6.--President Nimick, of the Pittsburg Ball Club, has been here to-day and left for home to-night.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Dec. 6.--The regular charter election was held here to-day, a light vote being polled. The Republicans gain one Councilman, having already a majority.

DETROIT, Mich., Dec. 6.--Mr. Don M. Dickinson, the new Postmaster-General, was born at Port Ontario, N.Y., but was brought to Detroit when a mere child, where he has ever since resided. He is now 42 years old. Graduating from the State University Law Department ...

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 6.--By the explosion of a boiler in Hogansville, near West Point, three negroes were killed this morning. Their names are James Harding, James Jones, and George Hinton, all operatives in the mill.

When old Wouter Van Twiller sat placidly in his arm chair and watched the smoke from his pipe float upward to the ceiling for 40 years without inquiring why it did so he made a picture of human felicity which the St. Nicholas Society deems it its duty to strive to attain at least once a year.

The art world and literary society will alike deplore the death which is announced tonight of Prof. Huxley's gifted daughter, the Hon. Mrs. Collier. In her brief married life her genius as an artist was not lost to the world.
TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 6.--United States Marshal Gordon has appointed his daughter, Alphonsine M. Gordon, a young lady just, out of her teens, as his deputy.

Among the steerage passengers of the Anchor steamship Anchoria, which arrived yesterday from Glasgow, was an American citizen of Chinese descent named Wong Kwai. He said that he came to this country 20 years ago, and showed naturalization papers which he had taken out.
An important step was taken yesterday at the meeting of the Directors of the Real Estate Exchange looking to the correction of the sham sales evil which has been explained at length in THE TIMES.

BERNE, Dec. 6.--The National Council has elected M. Kurz, of Aargan, President, and M. Ruffy, of Lausanne, Vice-President of that body. Both are Radicals.
The Telephone Committee, of which Assemblyman Ainsworth is Chairman, is in the city and will do a little more probing to-day.

At a meeting of the School Board of Flushing held in November a resolution was adopted which authorized the Superintendent of the Schools to administer corporal punishment when he deemed it necessary.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 6.--The forenoon session of the Harper trial was spent in placing before the jury more testimony concerning Harper's accounts and his peculiar methods. Several bookkeepers were examined on these points.

The County Democracy's County Committee met last evening in the Cooper Union. Police Commissioner John R. Voorhis acted as Chairman.

Trainor had his shoulder blade broken and Morley both thighs broken.

By a vote of 30 to 8 the Brooklyn Board of Education decided yesterday to dismiss Miss Harriet N. Morris, the Principal of Public School No. 39, Sixth-avenue, near Seventh-street. The dismissal takes effect on Jan. 31, 1888.

His physicians say there is no danger at present.

The New-York Commandery of the Military Order of the Loyal Legion of the United States overran Delmonico's last night. When they sat down to dinner the big dining room could not hold all, and a company of veterans were compelled to form a party in an adjoining room.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 7.--The Harper trial did not reach the close of the Government's testimony to-day, as was expected, but the same curious crowds gathered in all available places during the entire day. Howard Eckert, among other things, was asked to identify certain checks of his firm, which he did as follows:

LAS VEGAS, New-Mexico, Dec. 7.--The Board of Managers of the National Home for Disabled Volunteer Soldiers at a meeting last night made their final decision on the question of the location of the Pacific branch of the home.

The old chestnut that the Jerome Park Association's race track, at Fordham, is to be taken by the city for a storage reservoir and that the association has purchased lands for a new track, which can always be relied upon to make its appearance semi-weekly, was started on its rounds yesterday.

LEXINGTON, Dec. 7.--Bowerman Brothers, dealers in fine trotting stock, had one of their stables burned to-night, with five horses. One was a stallion, by Red wilkes, out of a mare by Mambrino Patchen, value $5,000, and a filly, by Wedgewood, value $1,500. The others ranged from $200 to $500. The loss is estimated at $8,000. The fire was of incendiary origin, it being started in three places.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 7.--To-day the Citizens' Committee appointed by the defunct Dime Savings Bank announced that the last of the bank's property would be sold this week, and that a final dividend would be declared, which it is hoped will be as large as 20 per cent. The depositors have already received 50 per cent. since the bank was wrecked by Arthur Ogilby.
TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 7.--The campaign for the election of a Commander of the NewJersey Department of the Grand Army of the Republic grows warmer every day.
The Trustees of the First Baptist Church, on Pierrepont-street, Brooklyn, met last evening to accept the resignation of their Pastor, the Rev. Dr. Jesse B. Thomas.

The "Vestibule Limited" on the NewYork Central Railway, in its arrangements for the comfort and convenience of passengers traveling between this city and Chicago, is a pronounced success. So, at least, agreed fourscore railway men who had every opportunity yesterday to note and discuss its novel and interesting features.

Mitchell Stone, alias Robert Bemis, alias A. Bemis, alias John Smith, was captured in Peekskill on Tuesday afternoon at a horse trot by Deputy Sheriff William Hallock. Officers have been looking for him for three years, as he has stolen a number of horses in Massachusetts, where indictments are awaiting him.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 7.--Detective Mintzhouser, under instructions of Police Superintendent Lamon, brought to a close this morning his investigation of five largely patronized "bucket shops" by a raid with a score of assistants.

W. H. Chalmers, importers of linens at 101 Franklin-street, made an assignment yesterday to Walter E. Phillips without preference. William Chalmers, the senior partner, lives in Scotland, and Harry Chalmers, the junior partner, is a resident of this city. They started business here in January, 1885, and made all their purchases in Scotland.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Dec. 7.--A young man named Henry M. Jackson, late a clerk in the United States Sub-Treasury at New-York, who absconded a couple of months ago with over $10,000 has been located here. He changed his stolen securities into Canadian money before crossing the border.
SIOUX CITY, Iowa, Dec. 7.--The Franz Brewing Company, of Sioux City, closed its doors yesterday morning, and the Selzer Brewery, following the example, shut down at noon.

"All hands to muster," was the call passed by the boatswain and his mates aboard RearAdmiral Luce's flagship, the Richmond, now lying alongside the cob dock at the Brooklyn Navy Yard, as a TIMES reporter stepped aboard ...
The Consolidated Gas Company and the Equitable Gas Company yesterday were notified to appear in the Court of General Sessions today and plead to indictments for misdemeanors ...
Signorina Teresina Tua's manager has given her up as a bad speculation. The fair violinist's concerts have not paid as it was expected they would.
Counsel for Nathan Barrett Mundy, the rich young Staten Islander who was put into the Middletown Insane Asylum by his relatives just as he was about to wed the pretty widow, ...

D. Burkinann, a Polish Hebrew, who arrived here last Thursday on the steamship State of Indiana, paid the passage to this country of Perl Cajesky with the understanding that her husband would repay the money. Yesterday the woman learned that her husband had forgotten her and married another woman.

The committees of citizens interested in the movement to celebrate the one hundredth anniversary of the inauguration of George Washington as first President of the United States met in Mayor Hewitt's office yesterday.
NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 7.--The British steamer Elysia, of the Anchor Line, arrived at her wharf this morning from Palermo, Italy, with 613 immigrants and a cargo of lemons from ...

BALTIMORE, Dec. 7.--Glenmore, the famous race horse, died of pneumonia a day or two ago at the stud farm of his owner, William Jennings, near this city. He was by Glen Athol, out of Lotta, and was 12 years old. His owner has won over $100,000 in purses with the great runner.
The St. Nicholas Club held a special meeting last evening to consider an amendment to the constitution which proposed to reduce the admission fee from $150 to $50.

Every year the officers of the Twelfth Regiment, National Guard, hold what is called the annual mess dinner. Last night, for the eleventh time, the officers sat down together for this annual mess at Delmonico's.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Dec. 7.--The Vandalia deal is not yet consummated. That much is certain, but the condition of things remains a conundrum to a great extent. The note due on the deal made with Ives last Summer was not paid in New-York to-day.

CHICAGO, Dec. 7.--In an interview to-day the Hon. J. B. Haviland, who is prominently connected with the copper mining interests of Northern Michigan, said that the reports from Calumet region were of a more serious nature than was at first believed to be possible.

Central Office Detectives Casper and McCord made a raid yesterday on a " bunko" game and headquarters for "green-goods" men at 166 Leonard-street, and arrested five men who were interested in the place.
Business circles are mildly excited over a war in express rates westward from Philadelphia in which the Adams and United States Express Companies are said to be engaged.

CARLISLE, Penn., Dec. 7.--John Rupp, the recently defeated Democratic candidate for Clerk of the Courts, has gone into court to contest the election of his rival, Willard F. Thompson, Republican, on the ground that the ticket of the latter reads "Clerk of the Courts," instead of "Clerk of the Courts and Recorder of Deeds." The county usually goes 1,000. Democratic, but gave Thompson a majority of 500.
There are at least Seven Wise Men in the city, but they are not all in the City Council.-- New-Orleans Pivayune.

CHICAGO, Dec. 7.--It can be stated positively that Receiver McNulta will on Dec. 15 reduce the Chicago and St. Louis rates on the Wabash from 53 to 40 cents on first class and in proportion on the other classes.
THE NEW-YORK TIMES had Swinburne's new tragedy, "Locrins," sent to it by cable, and published it in full in its regular edition.--The Writer.

ALBANY, Dec. 7.--All of the electrical corporations that have failed to pay their portion of the $80,000 assessed against them for the payment of the expenses and salary of the Subway Commissioners of New-York and Brooklyn will have an opportunity to settle with the Sheriff, the Controller having issued warrants for the collection thereof.

The trial of young Francis Hawkins for murder ended at Riverhead, Long Island, yesterday, and the jury rendered a verdict of guilty of murder in the first degree. The prisoner accepted the verdict with the greatest equanimity.

The Brooklyn New-England Society held its annual meeting in the art rooms of the Academy of Music last night and re-elected the following Directors: Benjamin D. Silliman, Hiram W. Hunt, George H. Fisher, Joseph F. Knapp, and John Winslow. The report of the Treasurer showed a cash balance of $14,500.21. The annual dinner will be held on Dec. 21.

TORONTO, Ontario, Dec. 7.--The Globe, referring to the President's message, says: "The message is unusually short and unusually important. Although it deals with only one subject no message so important has been sent by any President since the close of the great war.

The Executive Committee of the Jewelers' Security Alliance yesterday passed resolutions in honor of the late Algernon S. Sullivan, and voted to attend the funeral services in a body. Mr. Sullivan was counsel for the association.

PANAMA, Nov. 26.--Under the title of New-Bordeaux, a French colony is about to be founded between the rivers Paraguay and Bermejo, and in the region known as the Chaco Alto Peruane.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Dec. 7.--The Eastern Intercollegiate Football Association held its second meeting of the year in this city to-night and elected officers for the year. There were 10 delegates present, as follows: Institute of Technology--Durfee, Tracy, and Voice; ...

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 7.--The following news concerning the whereabouts and condition of Charles Stewart Parnell is obtained from Col. Peter L. Foy, a prominent citizen of St. Louis, who has just returned from Ireland. Col. Foy is an ex-editor of the Missouri Democrat.

Business men of all political creeds are nearly unanimous in their approval of the President's message. And one of their reasons for liking it, and liking it thoroughly, is its business-like way of setting forth cold facts.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 7.--About 50 of the farmers who live within two or three miles on each side of the line in Morris and Essex Counties have organized a society for protection against thieves. It is called Ely's Anti-Thief Association, and has its headquarters at Afton, where the Secretary and Treasurer, William F. Ely, lives.

Elijah P. Jenks, a veteran of the war of 1812, died on Saturday night at his home, 401 East Nineteenth-street, aged 87 years. He lacked a month and a day of being 13 years old when he enlisted in the Third New-York Regiment, ...

WILMINGTON, Del., Dec. 7.--An adjourned convention of the Episcopal Diocese of Delaware was held in this city to-day to elect a successor to the late Bishop Lee. There were 18 clerical and 43 lay delegates present. A twothirds vote of the clerical delegates was necessary to nominate and the lay delegates to confirm.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 7.--Information has been received of a desperate fight in a saloon at Georgetown, Eldorado County, between Frank Hellingsworth, aged 24, and his stepfather, George Handy, 50 years old. Both had been drinking.
The Brooklyn Young Men's Democratic Club is composed of divisions organized in the various wards of the city, and among the men who are dissatisfied with the rule of President ...

PORTLAND, Me., Dec. 7.--To-morrow the Argus will print a very striking letter from the Hon. J. W. Longley, Attorney-General of Nova Scotia. Mr. Longley says it is a misfortune that on both sides of the line the fishery question is obscured by party prejudices.

Halevy's "La Juive" was produced in its German form at the Metropolitan Opera House last evening in the presence of one of the largest audiences of the season.
Twenty-two of the local passenger trains of the New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad have now been equipped with the steam heating appliances.

The Rapid Transit Cable Company has been incorporated with a capital of $100,000 and the following Board of Trustees: John H. Pendleton, Cornelius Tiers, Alexander H. Tiers, Thomas Nast, Robert I. Sloane, Lincoln Moss, Thomas Swinyard, R. Duncan Harris, Andrew Bryson, Jr., Thomas L. Snead, John W. Young, H. H. McAllister, and Robert M. Miles.

President Winslow of the St. Louis and San Francisco arrived from New-York to be present at to-morrow's meeting of stockholders. The question before the meeting is the issue of bonds for the extension of the system in the Southwest.

PORT HURON, Mich., Dec. 7.--A freight train on the Grand Trunk Railway breke in two last night while descending the grade near Goodells Station. The front end was side tracked at the station, and while returning for the rear portion the engine came in collison with it, instantly killing Harry McGowan, brakeman, and severely injuring Jeffray, the engineer, and Robert McKay, fireman, The engine and cars were badly wrecked.

PANAMA, Nov. 26.--De Lesseps is certainly an inexplicable genius, to charitably interpret his recent announcement to the French Academy of Sciences that his canal across the American isthmus will be opened in 1890, and that, though it will not then be completed, it will admit the passage of 20 ships daily, or in the aggregate of 15,000,000 tons yearly.
CHICAGO, Dec. 7.--"The message of President Cleveland," said the Hon. W.D. Washburn of Minneapolis to-day, "is a bold and courageous document."

A.J. Cameron Co., of 61 Walkerstreet, are representative spinners and importers of wool yarns, who own extensive spinning mills in Philadelphia. W. P. Denegre, of that firm, said yesterday with reference to the President's message: "We are very much pleased with it.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7.--The leave of absence granted to First Lieut. Solomon E. Sparrow, Twentyfirst Infantry, has been extended two months. The leave of absence granted to First Lieut. Daniel C. Pearson, Second Cavalry, has been extended one month.
The Bald Eagle of Westchester flew back from his trip to the Western end of the State and arrived safely in this city yesterday morning. He has had ill luck in getting votes.
DUBLIN, Dec. 7.--The jury has brought in a verdict of acquittal in the case of O'Leary, one of the men charged with complicity in the murder of Constable Whelehan at Lisloonvarna, County Clare.
PPOVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 7.--In view of the prevalence of contagious diseases, the Woonsocket Town Council has voted to close all schools in town until Monday the 19th last.

John Jones in his day was one of the most celebrated characters of the old Sixth Ward. Although utterly illiterate, blind, and a drunkard, he amassed by keeping a junk shop real estate worth about $100,000.

The Pullman vestibule sleeping cars of the Pennsylvania Railroad's New-York and Chicago limited express, which left Chicago for the East yesterday afternoon, were equipped with a new and improved apparatus for heating by steam.

CONSTANTINOPLE, Dec. 7.--William K. Vanderbilt's yacht Alva has arrived here.

It was a dull day on the Produce Exchange yesterday --a marked contrast to the days that had preceded it. Wheat started at the closing prices of the previous night, and trade dragged until the afternoon, when there came an advance.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 7.--The officers of the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad Company have ordered that no more business for the United States Express Company shall be done by their road between New-York and Philadelphia.

Among Democrats, Independents, and business men of Brooklyn the President's message excited surprise, pleasure, and enthusiasm. All praised it and seconded its conclusions. Even Republicans admired the courage of the man who had done what the entire Democratic Party had been afraid to do.

The Fourth Precinct Station House, on Oak-street, is a nightly resort for the tramps at this season. Sixty of them sought its refuge from the chill air last night, and were treated to a genuine surprise by Dr. Cyrus Edson of the Health Department.

PARIS, Dec. 7.--President Carnot requested M. Fallieres to form a Cabinet, but M. Fallieres declined on the ground of ill health and a lack of sufficient authority. M. Fallieres's friends believe that he will eventually be induced to accept the task.

CITY OF MEXICO, via Galveston, Dec.7.-- Gen. Rocha, proprietor of El Combale newspaper, which is the avowed enemy of the Clericals and intensely hostile to the Jesuits, comes out to-day with a leader in favor of the re-election of President Diaz.

The effect of the old law, recently revived, that all auction sales in New-York shall be held between sunrise and sunset, was plainly visible at the opening of the D'Huyvester sale, at Moore's auction rooms, 290 Fifth-avenue, yesterday afternoon.

A fashionable church wedding yesterday was that of Miss Hildegarde Oeirichs to Richard Henderson, which took place at noon in St. George's Church, Stuyvesant-square. The Rev. Dr. William S. Rainsford, Rector of the church, performed the ceremony. All the details were arranged with a view to simplicity.

The Pacific Mail steamship Colon, which arrived yesterday from Aspinwall, brought 17 officers and 144 marines of the United States frigate Marion, who recently left that vessel at Panama. The Marion had completed a three years' cruise,during which she had circumnavigated the globe, but had spent the greater portion of the time in Asiatic waters.

LONDON, Dec. 7.--At the annual meeting of the Central Chamber of Agriculture to-day many provincial delegates were present and took part in an excited discussion over a motion favoring protection.

Recently a shingle at 165 West Twentythird-street announced that "Marianne Latouche, banker and broker," had an office there, and for a couple of weeks Inspector Byrnes has had to listen to a score of silly women who complained that Marianne's business methods were those of a swindler.
The Aqueduct Commissioners met yesterday and opened bids for the construction of the masonry work on the Sodom Dam, in the town of Southeast, Putnam County, this State.
The too enterprising persons who had projected an extension of the bridge to the Brooklyn City Hall have suddenly become discouraged, and are evidently on the point of acknowledging defeat.
James Carson Brevoort, who died yesterday morning at his residence, 36 Brevoortplace, Brooklyn, was an active worker in literary and scientific societies and institutions.

A raid was made upon a Chinese gambling den at 18 Mott-street last night, and 17 Chinamen, who might have enjoyed a night in the seductive pleasure of Fan Fan, are, owing to the vigilance of Capt. McCullagh, languishing in the cells of the Sixth Precinct Station.

The Board of Education, by a vote of 12 to 7, yesterday practically indorsed the action of the Trustees of the Seventeenth Ward in transferring Miss Julia L. Crinnion from School No. 79 to School No. 25 without giving her any notice before their action of a chance to give her substantial reasons for not deserving the transfer.

William J. Lardner, as attorney for Mrs. Daniel R. Lyddy, applied on Dec. 1 to Probate Clerk Beckett for the probate of her husband's will. Citations returnable on Jan. 24 were issued.
LONDON, Dec. 7.--The Stock Exchange closed with a stronger feeling.

PROVINCETOWN, Mass., Dec. 7.--Reports reached here to-day of the loss of the Provincetown schooner Lotta Bell, Capt. Ross, in the West Indies. No particulars were received. The Lotta Bell was built here in 1869. She registered 96 tons.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Dec. 8.--A fire broke out in Great Bend Village, Penn., at about 11 o'clock to-night and spread rapidly. It is now raging in the business portion of the village and the entire destruction of that section of the town is threatened. NORTH ADAMS, Mass., Dec. 9.--The report that typhoid fever was prevalent in Williams College is greatly exaggerated. In October Andrew Ray of Brooklyn left for home sick, and the symptoms devoloped into typhoid fever, from which he died early in November.

The annual meeting of Plymouth Church was held last night after the close of the prayer meeting, but there was so much business that the meeting had to be adjourned to next Friday evening. It was the fortieth annual meeting of the church. Thomas J. Tilney presided.

Esther Taber, widow of Corey Taber, died last Wednesday at her residence, 105 West Twenty-ninth-street. She was 96 years old, and up to a very few hours of her death retained her faculties, all but sight, unimpaired.

MONTREAL, Dec. 10.--A dispatch received here states that the Terrebonne College has been gutted by fire. The loss is $20,000; insured.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Dec. 11.--Deputy United States Marshal Thomas brought into Fort Smith, Ark., yesterday, the largest batch of criminals ever seen there at one time. They numbered 42. They all came from the Indian Territory, and will be tried in the United States courts.

CHICAGO, Dec. 12.--The success of the Citizen's Committee in bringing to Chicago the Republican National Convention has stimulated the members to make an earnest effort to secure for Chicago the Democratic Convention also. "The Democratic National Committee is to meet Feb. 22," said Warren Leland to-day, "and a committee has already been appointed to present our claims."

A paper on "Art and Morals," read by Anthony Comstock before the Baptist ministers at yesterday's meeting, and subsequent discussion thereon, made the meeting one of the most interesting, as it was one of the best attended, since the vacation season.

RONDOUT, N.Y., Dec. 12.--Germans here who are Catholics desire to dance and make merry in a quiet way over a glass or two of lager, but Archbishop Corrigan says there shall be neither within the pale of the church.
CARLISLE, Penn., Dec. 12.--Mrs. Hannah Brandt died at Churchtown, this county, to-day, in the one hundred and first year of her age.

Shall we or shall we not put ourselves on record as in favor of extending the Brooklyn Bridge beyond its present Brooklyn limits? was the question that interested the Bridge Trustees, off and on, from the beginning until the end of their meeting yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12.--The interruption of the negotiations by the Commissioners for the United States and Great Britain to settle the disputed fisheries question does not mean that the negotiations have failed. Halevy's "La Juive" was performed a second time at the Metropolitan Opera House last evening in the presence of an audience of fairly-large size and generous enthusiasm.
The annual election at the Real Estate Exchange yesterday passed without unusual incident.
The annual meeting of the Colored Orphan Asylum and Association for the Benefit of Colored Children was held yesterday at the residence of Mrs. S.G. Van Dusen, 65 West Thirtysixth-street.

LONDON, Dec. 12.--Mr. John Morley is seriously ill with an affection of the liver. All his political engagements have been canceled. He is greatly prostrated, and has been growing weaker since last evening.
WILKESBARRE, Penn., Dec. 12.--Mrs. Catharine Mekas, a well-known lady of this city, was suffocated by coal gas last night. Her son Alexander was unconscious when found, but recovered.

Niemann, the runaway Russian soldier, who was detained at Castle Garden, received, yesterday, $50 from a son of ex-Commissioner McElroy and $30 from a lady in Brooklyn. A letter came from his brother-in-law in Minnesota, telling him to trust in God, but inclosing no money. THE TIMES has received a check for $10 for him "E.J.H." He will start for the West this evening.
Miss Annie Kissam Warner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Warner, was married to Parker Douglas Handy at the Fifth-Avenue Presbyterian Church last evening.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Dec. 12.--George DeWolfe, an alleged French Count, is now lingering behind the bars of the Luzerne County Prison. The prisoner is a handsome man, above the medium height, and well dressed. He came to Wilkesbarre about six weeks ago in company with his bride-wife. The couple registered at the Wyoming Valley Hotel.

The Board of Trade and Transportation, which feels that it caused the telephone investigation, and therefore has a special interest in securing an elucidation of any doubtful points, yesterday sent out several hundred circulars to merchants of the city.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Dec. 12.--Seven weeks ago Dennis O'Connor, who lives on Portland-street, sustained internal injuries during a football game, from the effects of which he died yesterday. The injuries at first were not considered serious, but hemorrage set in and baflied medical skill. O'Connor was a young man of rare intelligence and excellent character, and intended to enter Wesleyan University next year.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 12.--Judge Thayer to-day issued an injunction restraining until further orders George C. Brotherton from producing the opera of "The Little Tycoon" at the Ninth and Arch Street Dime Museum which had been advertised as the stage attraction there this week.
There will be a lively time to-night at 156 East Fifty-fourth-street, where an election for Commander of Reno Post, No. 44, G. A. R., will be held.

CHICAGO, Dec. 12.--President O.W. Potter, of the North Chicago Rolling Mills, laughed to-day at the idea that the closing of the Joliet steel works is due to the tariff policy recommended in the message of President Cleveland, and said he did not believe the Joliet company had desired any such notion to go out.
INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Dec. 12.--On Saturday afternoon the citizens of Owensborough, Ky., observed an immense balloon sailing over that city at a great height.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12.--Col. Rufus Saxton, A.Q.G., has been directed to return to his home at Washington, D.C., to await retirement.
NEVADA, Mo., Dec. 12.--A mistake that resulted in the death of two prominent citizens of this city occurred in the woods of Ozark County Saturday.
PARIS, Dec. 12.--Aubertin, the man who shot M. Ferry in the lobby of the Chamber of Deputies on Saturday, was before a Judge today. He showed symptoms of lunacy and his examination was postponed.

John C. Nobis, as the Assignee of Charles Nobis, has filed his schedules in the Court of Common Pleas. He puts the liabilities at $4,691.10, the nominal assets at $5,029.50, and the actual assets at $192.

Early yesterday morning the fog lifted and a fleet of over 20 steamships which had been delayed entered port. Some of the steamers reported that they ran into the fog 80 miles oil Sandy Hook. Others reported that they were off Sandy Hook soon after the fog set in. Several vessels which arrived yesterday reported stormy experiences.

BOSTON, Dec. 12.--Edwin Booth and Lawrence Barrett began their engagement at the Boston Theatre to-night before an immense audience. The opening play, "Julius Caesar," with Booth as Brutus, Barrett as Cassius, and Buckley as Antony, was elaborately staged. There seemed to be no limit to the enthusiasm, and Mr. Buckley shared four recalls. The advance sale of seats for this engagement has been very large.
CHICAGO, Dec. 12.--One of the latest of Col. McCaull's pieces, "The Bellman," met with great success at the Chicago Opera House this evening.
Thomas Clifford and Christopher Glennan quarreled on June 27 and went into the yard of 406 East Forty-sixth-street to settle it, the invitation to do so coming from Glennan.

BOSTON, Dec. 12.--Gen. Banks, United States Marshal, this morning removed, or thought he did, two of his deputies--Gallupe and Snow.

The steamship Barracouta, which arrived yesterday from Demerara, brought the crew of the British schooner Henrietta, which was abandoned on Dec. 7 in latitude 24 26' and longitude 67 12'. This crew is one of the few on record who can boast of having been rescued by moonlight.
Special Treasury Agents have made another valuable discovery in searching through the Public Stores in the course of the general investigation set on foot by Collector Magone.

HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 12.--The Yale Alumni Association to-night re-elected its old officers, the Rev. J.H. Twichell, Class of '59, President, and the Hon. Henry C. Robinson, Class of '53, VicePresident. It was decided to hold an informal meeting in January and to omit the formal dinner.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 12.--It was published semi-officially yesterday that there will not be a resumption of dividends upon the stock of the Cincinnati, New-Orleans and Texas Pacific Railroad, although there has been an increase...

LONDON, Dec. 12.--Advices from Samoa, under date of Nov. 30, state that the Germans continue to occupy the islands. Apia is quiet. The position of Tamasese, who was declared King by the Germans after the deposition of King Malietoa, is weak. A majority of the natives have paid the poll tax.
ELMIRA, N.Y., Dec. 12.--Robert H. Walker, Chief Engineer of the Elmira Fire Department, placed his resignation in the hands of Fire Commissioner George H. Robinson to-night.

What was termed a "Great Salvation Army demonstration" was held last night at the Salvation Temple, in Jane-street, in honor of the National Staff Council. The council held a meeting at the Lyceum, in Washington-street, Brooklyn, in the afternoon.
HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 12.--A temperance movement has been inaugurated here by the manufacturing concerns, which promises to drive the liquor traffic off one large section of the city.

Horatio H. Barling was a member of the Consolidated Stock and Petroleum Exchange when he died, July 13, 1885, and his widow and children became entitled to $8,000 out of the gratuity fund of the Exchange.
AKRON, Ohio, Dec. 12.--The through freight on the New-York, Pennsylvania and Ohio Road in this city last night ran into a local freight.

The National Convention of Republican Clubs will be called to order in Chickering Hall at 11 o'olock, Thursday morning next. If the expectations of those who have been immediately concerned in calling the convention are realized, at least 1,000 and possibly 1,500 delegates will attend.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 12.--The State Agricultural Society began balloting for certain officers at noon to-day, and continued to do so all afternoon and evening. At the annual election of the society in January Thomas L. Harrison, who had filled the office of Secretary, was defeated for the position by J.S. Woodward.

MOSCOW, Dec. 12.--The disturbances created by the students of the university here have become so serious that lectures have been suspended and meetings of students are forbidden. In a recent fracas between the students and a body of troops one student was killed and several were wounded. Hundreds of others were arrested.
CHICAGO, Dec. 12.--A fire broke out about 7:30 o'clock to-night in the very centre of the most valuable business property in Chicago.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Dec. 12.--The meeting advertised by the anti-saloon Republicans to be held in the Young Men's Christian Association Building here to-night was not very numerously attended.

ALBANY, Dec. 12.--Bank Superintendent Willis S. Paine has issued a certificate authorizing the Southside Bank, of Bay Shore, N.Y., to transact a general banking business under the State laws, with paid-up capital of $25,000. Richard M. Raven, President and Tredwell O. Smith, Vice-President.

BOSTON, Dec. 12.--A shooting affair, which will result in murder, took place at an early hour this morning in the Dorchester district.

The annual meeting of the Manhattan Athletic Club was held last evening and the reports were most gratifying from a membership and pecuniary point of view.

NORTH ADAMS, Mass., Dec. 13.--William W. Nichols, 66 years old, a well-known circus rider and proprietor, died here at home on Meadow-street early this morning of apoplexy.

The second dock trial of the United States steel cruiser Chicago, which came off yesterday, was as successful as the first one, and the cruiser will be prepared at once to go down the Sound on her final trial trip. Herr August Junkermann, the German actor, gave late farewell performance to this country at the Thalia Theatre last evening. He has made many friends during his brief stay here, and numbers of them were on hand last evening to give him a parting cheer.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 13.--Robert Garrett has finally decided on the transpacific trip. A private telegram received here to-day says that he and his party will sail from San Francisco for Japan and India, and will then continue upon a tour around the world. The health of the party is reported good.

Coroner Lindsay of Brooklyn was notified yesterday that Sarah Hicks, a young daughter of ex-Supervisor Hicks, had died suddenly at the residence of her brother-in-law, Frank Masterson, 108 Vernon-avenue, it was thought, of heart disease.

The footpad who, last Friday afternoon at Prince and Mott streets, robbed Adolph Bach, the aged jewelry maker of 39 Grand-street, of a $300 diamond scarf-pin, was arrested Wednesday evening. He is Michael, or "Wreck," Donovan, or Johnson, and his captors, Detectives Crowley and Maguire, picked him up at Second-avenue and Firststreet. He was fully identified by Mr. Bach and his daughter, and persons who saw the robbery committed.

He stated that she was a witch, and had caused sickness and death in his family. He hung a cross on the gate in the name of the Trinity, hence she was unable to enter, and fell and bruised herself.

The suit of Dr. Henry B. Whitehorne against Henry Walker for $1,200 on account of professional services rendered by the plaintiff to Mrs. Isabella Walters, which has been on trial in the Newark Circuit Court for two days, was terminated yesterday afternoon, when the jury brought in a verdict in favor of the doctor for $17.50.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Dec. 15.--The annual meeting of the New York State League Anti-Saloon Republicans began at Music Hall this afternoon. Col. E.P. Hill of Brooklyn presided. There was a good attendance, including representative men from all parts of the State. An address of welcome to the city by J.B. Brooks was responded to by the Chairman. The session will continue two days, closing with a mass meeting.

ALBANY, Dec. 15.--Assemblymen Fremont Cole and Charles Saxton reached Albany this afternoon, and the former at once took the Hon. Vreeland H. Youngman, Assemblyman from the Second Albany District, into his confidence.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15.--Over $1,000,000 worth of valuable papers and money were recovered this morning from the iron vaults in the ruins of the Phelps, Dodge Palmer shoe factory.

ALBANY, Dec. 15.--Regents of the University Pierson, Reid, Curtis, Harris, McKelway, and Beach, the committee looking to the reorganization of the State Library, will meet in New-York on the 20th inst. to inspect the various libraries there and consult with eminent librarians. HALLOWELL, Me., Dec. 16.--Gov. Bodwell died this morning. At midnight last night it was stated by friends of the Governor that though he had not rested for the past three nights as well as he had done before, he had no cough and no pain, and his breathing was clear and easy.

COLUMBUS, Miss., Dec. 16.--The large brick livery stable of Hatzell Sherrod was burned last night. The upper portion was filled with teedstuffs. The vehicles were saved and all the horses were gotten safely out, but 12 of them ran back into the burning stable and perished in the flames.

CHARLES CITY, Iowa, Dec.16.--Chester Bellows was hanged at 10:46 o'clock this forenoon. He had to be supported to the gallows, and as the rope was placed around his neck he exclaimed three times: "Please don't." his the Sheriff placed the white cap over his head he exclaimed again: "Please don't. I am innocent." The trap was sprung at 10:46 and in eight minutes and forty seconds his heart ceased to beat. His neck was broken.

COLUMBUS, Ark., Dec. 17.--Charles Whitsott, a half-witted boy, aged 13, went out walking with his young brother, aged 9, and his sister, aged 6. PITTSBURG, Dec. 17--The converting, blooming, and rail departments of the Edger Thompson Steel Works at Braddocks, Penn., were closed down to-day and the employes notified that for the present there would be no work for them. It is understood that the rail mill suspension is for an indefinite period, but that the blooming and converting departments will resume after the annual reparis have been made. The shut-down will throw several thousand men out of employment.

Mme. White, the well-known fashionable milliner, died last week from the effects of an opearation for cancer. For the first day or two after the operation she was fairly well, but she suddenly got worse and died. In view of the discussions that are now going on in the medical profession about the possibility of cancer being infectious, it is a curious fact that her husband is suffering from the same malady.

ALBANY, Dec. 19.--Justice Learned sat in Circuit Court this afternoon. He stated that Justice Mayham, who had intended to be present and hold the balance of the term, had been prevented by missing a train, and that he simply came at Justice Mayham's request to adjourn the court.

TILTON, Ga., Dec. 19.--At 1 P.M. to-day a boiler at S.M. Winchester's sawmill exploded while all the hands were around the furnance doors warming themselves. Five men were instantly killed and a boy was seriously injured. The killed are: Ellison Hembre, James Walker, William Tennaman, Edward Hogan, and A. Hawkins, the last two colored. Their bodies were frightfully mutilated.

McGREGOR, Iowa, Dec. 21.--Two passenger trains on the St. Paul Road collided at Jackson Junction early this morning. Miss Louise A. Smith, a colored lady from Connecticut with aspirations as a dramatist produced one of her own efforts at Chickering Hall last night, for the benefit of the Colored Vigilance Committee. It was in three acts, and was entitled "The Little Mountain Fairies."

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Dec. 23.--Miss Triphenia Bevens, an old resident of Danbury and one of the oldest persons in this State, died in Danbury last night, aged nearly 102 years. She was born April 14, 1786, and had always lined in Danbury. Her husband, Henry Beveils, served in the war of 1812 and took part in several engagements. Mrs. Bevens was a pensioner. She retained all her faculties up to the time of her death.

John Powell, one of the Dobbs Ferry burglars, yesterday at White Plains pleaded guilty to burglary in the first degree, and Justice Bartlett sentenced him to 17 years' imprisonment in Sing Sing Prison.

Emiliano P. Bergamini, an old banker of this city and one of the Italian revolutionists of 1848, died on Thursday at his residence, 193 Alexander-avenue, from a complication of kidney and lung troubles.

The American Jockey Club has arranged to hold its Spring meeting at Jerome Park, beginning on May 29, and continuing to June 12 inclusive. The Fall meeting will begin on Oct. 2 and terminate on Oct. 15.

HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 23.--Judge Carpenter to-day appointed ex-Lieut. Gov. L.H. Cooke of Riverton and the Hon. John R. Buck of Hartford Receivers of the Continental Life Insurance Company and granted a decree of Receivership. Policy holders' claims must be sent in by July 1, 1888.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Dec. 23.--An explosion of dynamite at a limestone quarry near Brookfield, Colchester County, this morning killed four men, one of them being Alexander McDonald, proprietor of the quarry. They were warming dynamite previous to using it for a blast, when it exploded, it is supposed from overheating. A man and a woman who were present escaped with slight injuries. The building was destroyed.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Dec. 24.--Patrolman Cook last night saw a burglar at work and tried to arrest him. He threw something at the officer, which struck him on the head and exploded, fracturing the skull. It is supposed to have been dynamite. Cook is in a critical condition, but may recover.
